2. The study of Kauffman networks has also led to the identification of relevant elements, which are the only ones that can influence the long-time behavior of the system. The relevant elements are identified using an algorithm that eliminates stable and irrelevant variables. The number of relevant elements was found to scale as a power law of the system size in the chaotic phase, and as a stretched exponential in the frozen phase. The study of Kauffman networks has also led to the discovery of finite-size effects, which are due to the periodic dynamics of the random networks.
</summary>

<summary>
1. The study of turbulence in quantum fluids, specifically in quantum turbulence (QT) and spin-superflow turbulence (SST), has shed new light on our understanding of turbulence. In QT, many quantized vortices with quantized circulation are nucleated, forming tangles, which is drastically different from classical turbulence (CT) realized in classical fluids.

2. The study of SST in a spin-1 ferromagnetic spinor Bose-Einstein condensate (BEC) has found that both the -5/3 and 1 power laws appear in the spectrum of the superflow kinetic and the spin-dependent interaction energy. The -5/3 power law is generated by the nonlinear spin term in the velocity motion equation.

3. Numerical results of the spin-1 spinor Gross-Pitaevskii (GP) equation with a phenomenological small-scale energy dissipation term have confirmed the appearance of both power laws in the two-dimensional system. The inertial term is smaller than the nonlinear spin term in the range of the density coherence length.

4. The study has also discussed the dependence of the spectra on the relative velocity, finding that the period sustaining the Kolmogorov spectrum in the superflow kinetic energy becomes short when the relative velocity is large. The spectrum of the spin-dependent interaction energy, however, can exhibit the 1 power law independently of the relative velocity.
</summary>

<summary>

1. Low-luminosity active galactic nuclei (LLAGNs) reside in about 40% of nearby bright galaxies and occupy the majority of the population of AGNs. Their low luminosities are thought to be caused by very low accretion rates onto supermassive black holes.

2. The accretion model of optically-thin discs, such as the advection-dominated accretion flow (ADAF), is often used to explain the low luminosities of LLAGNs. This model predicts a "submillimetre bump" in the spectral-energy distribution (SED) of LLAGNs.

3. The ADAF model is crucial in understanding the radio sources of LLAGNs, and observational evidence of the ADAF is essential to confirm its existence. However, there is a significant gap between observations and the ADAF spectrum, especially at low-frequency radio bands.

4. The submillimetre bump means a highly inverted spectrum at centimetre-to-submillimetre wavelengths, which is a key feature of the ADAF model. Observations for LLAGNs have been carried out exclusively at centimetre bands due to their faintness.

5. About half of low-luminosity Seyfert galaxies and low-ionization nuclear emission-line regions (LINERS) hold a compact radio core, and at least 25% of transition objects also hold a compact core. Most of the cores show nearly flat spectra, indicating jet domination.

6. The contamination from jets has prevented the ADAF from being revealed at centimetre bands, and high-frequency observations are promising to detect the inverted spectrum of the ADAF. The use of a beam as small as possible and estimations of every conceivable contamination are essential.

7. The present paper reports millimetre survey and submillimetre data analyses for many LLAGNs, and the observational evidence of the ADAF is crucial in understanding the radio sources of LLAGNs. The high-frequency radio survey has greatly expanded the frequency range of submillimetre-bump hunting.

8. Our findings will encourage further LLAGN surveys at higher-frequency ranges with the coming Atacama Large Millimeter and Submillimetre Array (ALMA) to prove the ADAF. The existence of the ADAF will give radio astronomers a chance to make the direct imaging for accretion discs.

9. The ADAF model predicts a high brightness temperature of 10^12 K in radio bands, which is expected to be detected with future Very-

<summary>

1. The scattering, absorption, and reradiation of photons by dust grains affect the propagation of starlight and play a key role in regulating the energy balance in the interstellar medium. Studies of these processes have provided a great deal of insight into the physical and chemical properties of dust grains.

2. The degree of absorption and scattering by dust depends on the wavelength of the incident radiation, and this dependence can be quantified in terms of the normalized dust extinction law, also known as the reddening law. The ratio of total to selective extinction is a commonly used measure of the slope of the extinction/reddening law.

3. Galactic dust displays a wide range of behavior, and while diffuse interstellar dust is observed to have a certain average value of the extinction law slope, this value is not universal and can vary significantly from one line of sight to another. Significant deviations from this canonical value are known to exist for a variety of interstellar dust clouds.

4. The extinction law slope can be measured using various methods, including the use of broad-band photometry in light of the fact that an extensive suite of photometric data sets is currently available. Three methods for measuring the extinction law slope are proposed in this paper.

5. The first two methods rely on accurate three-band optical photometry of cluster stars, while the third method relies on two-band optical photometry and a map of the dust thermal emission. All three methods are based on the premise that the width of the blue horizontal branch (HB) is minimized when the appropriate extinction law slope value is used to correct the photometry for extinction and reddening.

6. The methods are applied to NGC 4833, a low-latitude galactic globular cluster with variable extinction across its face. Realistic Monte Carlo simulations of the cluster data set are used to estimate the accuracy with which the extinction law slope can be recovered.

7. The results from the three methods are combined to give a mean extinction law slope of 2.74 for the line of sight towards NGC 4833. The scatter in the cluster HB is used to estimate the amount of small-scale structure in the dust complex in the foreground of NGC 4833.

</summary>

<summary>
1. The Kondo lattice model (KLM) is used to study the heavy fermion systems, which are characterized by a hierarchy of energy scales. The KLM describes an array of localized magnetic moments coupled antiferromagnetically to a metallic host of mobile conduction electrons.

2. The dynamical cluster approximation (DCA) is used to investigate the KLM ground state, and the results show that the quasi-particles of the heavy fermion liquid remain intact across the magnetic order-disorder transition. The DCA approach allows for antiferromagnetic order, enabling the computation of spectral functions across magnetic transitions and in magnetically ordered phases.

3. The single-particle spectral function is calculated using the DCA+QMC approach, and the results show that the quasi-particle weight decreases continuously across the transition from the paramagnetic to the antiferromagnetic state. The spectral function also shows a feature reminiscent of the heavy-fermion band, indicating the absence of kondo breakdown throughout the phase diagram.

4. The transition from the paramagnetic to the antiferromagnetic state is continuous and is associated with the backfolding of the large heavy fermion Fermi surface. The Fermi surface topology change within the antiferromagnetic metallic phase corresponds to two continuous Lifshitz transitions, as suggested by a mean-field modeling of the quantum Monte Carlo results.
</summary>

<summary>

1. The recent discovery of a resonance at 125 GeV at the Large Hadron Collider (LHC) is compatible with the expectations for the Higgs particle, representing a major step towards understanding the origin of the mass of fundamental particles. This discovery may also affect the field of gravitation, particularly in models where the Higgs field has nonminimal coupling to the general relativity sector. The Higgs field may be responsible for inflation and as a suppression mechanism for the contribution to dark energy expected from quantum fields.

2. The LHC experiments have provided upper bounds on the gravitational interaction of Higgs bosons, and bounds on the crosstalk between the Higgs particle and gravity may also be obtained by considering strong-gravity astrophysical objects, such as active galactic nuclei (AGN) and primordial black holes. The presence of a strong spacetime curvature deforms the vacuum expectation value of the Higgs field and therefore the mass of fundamental particles. Nucleons are minimally affected by the strong curvature since most of their mass arises from the gluonic fields that are not coupled to the Higgs field at tree level.

3. Peculiar wavelength shifts are predicted for electronic transitions and are strongly suppressed for molecular transitions in which the main role is played by the nuclei themselves, such as in vibrational or rotational spectroscopy. Due to the vanishing of the Ricci scalar for spherically symmetric objects, attention was focused on the possibility of couplings to the only non-zero curvature invariant, the Kreschmann invariant. The Kreschmann invariant plays an important role in quadratic theories of gravity and modified theories of gravity.

4. White dwarfs have been known since the 19th century and have had a prominent role in fundamental physics since the early 20th century. They have been used to verify general relativity by measuring the gravitational redshift of Sirius B and to study the dependence of the fine structure constant on gravity. White dwarfs can be used to obtain limits on the coupling of the Higgs field to a specific curvature invariant by means of spectroscopic observations.

5. The analysis is complemented by considering data taken from the HST archive on a second white dwarf, Procyon B, in which Caii and MgII lines, in addition to the C3 bands, are also present. The search for coupling between the Higgs (or any scalar field permeating the whole universe) and spacetime curvature arises naturally within the framework of field theory in curved spacetime.

<summary>
1. White dwarf (WD) stars, specifically those with hydrogen-rich atmospheres (DA WDs), are found to pulsate in a temperature range known as the ZZ Ceti instability strip, with the pulsations driven by non-radial modes.
2. The discovery of pulsating extremely low-mass (ELM) WDs, which are likely helium-core WDs, has expanded the understanding of the ZZ Ceti instability strip and its relation to the evolution of low-mass WDs.
3. The pulsating ELM WDs, including the two newly discovered WDs J1614 and J2228, have effective temperatures below 11,000 K, making them the coolest pulsating WDs ever found, and their study offers opportunities to constrain physical and evolution models of ELM WDs.
</summary>

<summary>
1. The interstellar medium (ISM) of a typical disk galaxy is divided into various phases, including hot ionized gas, warm neutral medium, and cold neutral medium. Star formation appears to be restricted to cold dense gas, and the molecular gas content strongly correlates with the star formation rate. The link between star formation and molecular gas is not causal, but molecular gas represents an indispensable tracer of star-forming regions. Understanding these links is crucial for identifying the pathways and conditions under which cold, molecular gas develops.

2. The gas temperature sets the characteristic size and mass of prestellar cores that develop in post-shock regions within magnetized, star-forming clouds. Young, massive stars are the main source of far-ultraviolet (FUV) photons that permeate the ISM and readily photodissociate interstellar molecules. Molecular gas is found predominantly in dense, cold regions where dust shielding and self-shielding have attenuated the interstellar radiation field. The transition zones separating atomic and molecular gas, known as photodissociation regions (PDRs), have been studied extensively both numerically and theoretically.

</summary>

<summary>
1. The authors argue that the vertical extension of the red clump (VRC) in the Large Magellanic Cloud (LMC) is due to stellar evolution, specifically the blue loops experienced by intermediate-mass stars in their helium-core burning phase, rather than an intervening population of non-LMC stars.
2. The authors' conclusion is supported by the presence of the VRC in all their LMC fields, its agreement with the time-averaged locus of the blue loops, and its relative stellar density consistent with the density on the main sequence and the assumption of continuous and constant star formation history in the LMC over the past 1 gyr.
</summary>

<summary>

1. The study investigates the dependence of star formation on cluster mass and location within a cluster in 69 local galaxy clusters. The cluster membership is determined from SDSS DR7 spectroscopic redshifts for galaxies brighter than m_r = 17.5, and star formation rates are determined with 22 μm photometry from WISE using the relations outlined in Jarrett et al. (2011). The study finds that both the fraction of demi-LIRGs and the mean specific SFR of cluster galaxies increase with projected distance from the cluster center. However, the fraction of demi-LIRGs remains below the field value even at 3 times the cluster virial radius.

2. The study also investigates the impact of cluster mass on star formation by presenting the total cluster SFR normalized by M_200 as a function of M_200. The results show no evidence of a correlation between the cluster specific SFR and cluster mass in this first uniform dataset to detect obscured star formation out to several times the virial radius in a large sample of low-redshift clusters. This indicates that cluster mechanisms which scale with cluster mass, such as ram pressure or harassment, are not likely to play a dominant role in the evolution of star formation in local clusters. The study suggests that strangulation, a mechanism that is not strongly dependent on cluster mass, may be the dominant process for regulating star formation in dense environments.

3. The study uses data from WISE and SDSS DR7 to study the dependence of star formation on cluster mass and location within a cluster. The results show that the fraction of demi-LIRGs is suppressed at large radii, which may be due to galaxies being pre-processed in intermediate-density environments or the contribution of a "backsplash" population. The study also finds that the mean specific SFR of cluster galaxies increases with projected distance from the cluster center, but remains below the field value even at 3 times the cluster virial radius. The results suggest that star formation is quenched in a significant population of galaxies within small groups or filaments.

4. The study's results are consistent with previous studies that have found no significant correlation between cluster specific SFR and cluster mass. The study's findings suggest that the dominant process for regulating star formation in dense environments does not depend on cluster mass, and hence must be efficient in small groups or filaments. The study's results also imply that even in low-mass groups, star formation has already been quenched to similar levels observed in clusters that are more massive

<summary>
1. The Bishop-Phelps-Bollobás property (BPP) is a concept in functional analysis that deals with the density of norm-attaining operators in the space of all bounded linear operators. A pair of Banach spaces (X, Y) satisfies the BPP if for every x in the unit sphere of X and every ε > 0, there exists a norm-attaining operator T from X to Y such that ||T|| = 1 and ||Tx - x|| < ε. The BPP has been studied extensively, and several results have been obtained, including the fact that every finite-dimensional space satisfies the BPP.

2. The strong Bishop-Phelps-Bollobás property (SBPP) is a generalization of the BPP that deals with the density of norm-attaining operators in the space of all bounded linear operators. A pair of Banach spaces (X, Y) satisfies the SBPP if for every x in the unit sphere of X and every ε > 0, there exists a norm-attaining operator T from X to Y such that ||T|| = 1 and ||Tx - x|| < ε, and T attains its norm at some point in the unit sphere of X. The SBPP has been studied in several papers, and several results have been obtained, including the fact that every finite-dimensional space satisfies the SBPP.

3. The uniform SBPP is a version of the SBPP that deals with the density of norm-attaining operators in the space of all bounded linear operators, where the constant ε depends only on the norm of the operator. A pair of Banach spaces (X, Y) satisfies the uniform SBPP if for every ε > 0, there exists a constant δ > 0 such that for every x in the unit sphere of X and every operator T from X to Y with ||T|| = 1, there exists a norm-attaining operator S from X to Y such that ||S|| = 1, ||Sx - x|| < ε, and S attains its norm at some point in the unit sphere of X. The uniform SBPP has been studied in several papers, and several results have been obtained, including the fact that every finite-dimensional space satisfies the uniform SBPP.

4. The paper studies the SBPP and the uniform SBPP in several Banach spaces, including the space of all bounded linear operators from a Banach space X to a Banach space Y.

<summary>
1. The frozen nucleon approximation is a method to calculate the inclusive 2p-2h responses in the relativistic fermi gas model, which reduces the number of nested integrals from 7 to 1, making it a fast and efficient approach. This approximation assumes that the momenta of the initial nucleons can be neglected for high enough values of the momentum transfer. The method has been validated by comparing the approximate 2p-2h response functions with exact results in the rfg. The frozen approximation works well for momentum transfers above the fermi momentum.

2. The validity of the frozen approximation relies on the fact that the integrand inside the 2p-2h response is a function that depends slowly on the momenta of the two initial nucleons inside the fermi sea. However, the forward delta-excitation term requires a special treatment, and an effective propagator for the delta resonance has been introduced to average over the fermi gas. The frozen approximation has been compared with the shell model results and found to be in good agreement. The approach can be used to implement 2p-2h models in monte carlo event generators, making it a useful tool for neutrino oscillation experiments.

<summary>
1. The mass of a supermassive black hole (SMBH) in active galactic nuclei (AGN) is correlated with the luminosity, mass, and velocity dispersion of the stellar spheroid of the galaxy. This correlation may imply an evolutionary relation between the growth of the SMBH and the host galaxy. To study the dependence of various observed phenomena of AGN on the black hole mass and cosmic evolution, independent and reliable estimates of the mass of the black holes are required. One independent method to estimate the mass of the black hole is using the reverberation mapping technique.

2. The reverberation mapping technique involves measuring the time lag between the variations of the broad emission line and the continuum emission. This time lag can be used to estimate the size of the broad line region (BLR) and the mass of the black hole. The technique has been used to make estimates of SMBH masses over a large range of redshift, but it is observationally taxing and requires a large amount of telescope time. The authors present the optical spectroscopic and photometric observations of a new low-luminosity AGN, H 0507 + 164, and estimate the mass of the SMBH using the reverberation mapping technique.

<summary>
1. The broad emission iron lines found in active galactic nuclei and black hole binaries are thought to originate close to the black hole through the reflection of primary radiation on the accretion disc. The spin of the black hole plays a crucial role in shaping the line, particularly in determining the position of the marginally stable orbit.

2. The Laor model, a widely used relativistic disc spectral line model, has been limited to a maximally rotating Kerr black hole, but this limitation has been relaxed in the Ky model. The Ky model allows for the dimensionless angular momentum to be fitted, providing more flexibility in data fitting procedures.

3. The Laor model can still be used to estimate the spin of the black hole by identifying the inner edge of the disc with the marginally stable orbit. However, the Ky model provides a more accurate representation of the relativistic line profile.

4. The Laor and Ky models were compared using data from the XMM-Newton satellite and artificial data generated for the XEUS mission. The results showed that the Ky model provides a better-defined minimum for the spin parameter and more regularly shaped confidence contour plots.

5. The Laor model tends to overestimate the spin value and has insufficient energy resolution, which affects the correct determination of the high-energy edge of the broad line. The discrepancies between the two models are more visible, especially for lower values of the spin.

6. The correct re-binning of the data with respect to the instrumental energy resolution is crucial to obtain statistically relevant results. The study highlights the importance of using accurate models and data analysis techniques to determine the spin of black holes.
</summary>

<summary>

1. The "displace, cut and reflect" method is used to generate axially symmetric solutions of Einstein's field equations, which can be used as models of galaxies or accretion disks. This method involves displacing a compact source of gravitational field, cutting it, and reflecting the remaining space to create a disk with a singularity. The method can be applied to any spacetime solution of the Einstein equations with or without a source. The resulting disk can have a positive energy density and equal radial and azimuthal pressures, making it a perfect fluid.

2. The method is applied to the Schwarzschild metric in isotropic coordinates to generate a disk with surface energy density and radial and azimuthal pressures given by specific equations. The total mass of the disk can be calculated using the Einstein equations, and the disk's surface energy density is always positive, satisfying the weak energy condition. The strong energy condition is also satisfied, indicating that the disk is made of matter with the usual gravitational attractive property. The velocity of sound propagation is also calculated, and the condition that it is less than the speed of light is satisfied.

3. The method is also applied to the Buchdahl solution, which represents a fluid sphere with no boundary, to generate a disk with energy density, pressure, and sound velocity given by specific equations. The conditions for the energy density and pressure to be positive are satisfied, and the velocity of sound is also calculated. The tangential velocity of test particles in circular motion is calculated, and the specific angular momentum is also determined. The stability of circular orbits on the disk's plane is studied using an extension of Rayleigh's criteria of stability.

4. The method is applied to other solutions of the Einstein equations, including the Narlikar-Patwardhan-Vaidya (NPV) solutions, to generate disks with halos. The NPV solutions represent a sphere of perfect fluid with a specific metric function, and the disk generated from these solutions has energy density, pressure, and sound velocity given by specific equations. The tangential velocity of test particles in circular motion is also calculated, and the specific angular momentum is determined. The stability of circular orbits on the disk's plane is studied, and regions of unstable orbits are found for certain parameters.

</summary>

<summary>
1. The creation of two interpenetrating superfluids is a long-sought goal in low-temperature physics, and recent experiments have made significant progress in achieving this goal.
2. Early efforts focused on mixtures of helium isotopes, but more recent experiments have used Bose-Einstein condensates (BEC) of atomic gases to create systems where two species of atoms condense simultaneously.
3. The dynamics of the complex relative motion of the condensates has been studied, and the possibility of measuring the relative phase between the two condensates has been demonstrated.
4. Theoretical investigation of two-component BEC systems has a long history, dating back to the construction of phenomenological hydrodynamic equations in the spirit of the Landau-Khalatnikov two-fluid model.
5. Recent experiments with alkali atoms have revived interest in the theory of two-component BEC systems, and Hartree-Fock theory has been successfully tested on the two-component rubidium system.
6. The stability, ground-state properties, and collective excitations of two-component BEC systems have been studied theoretically using the Gross-Pitaevskii equations.
7. The existence of a domain wall solution in binary BEC with a coupling drive can be shown in a simple way by focusing on fluctuations of the fields on length scales much larger than the largest healing length.
8. The domain wall solution is formally similar to the kink in the sine-Gordon field theory, but it is not topologically stable and can decay.
9. The decay of the wall occurs via hole nucleation, and the decay rate is exponentially suppressed by the WKB factor or the Boltzmann factor, depending on the temperature.
10. The crossover temperature, below which crossover proceeds via quantum tunneling rather than via thermal activation, is estimated to be of the order of a few nanokelvin, given typical parameters of present-day experiments.
</summary>

<summary>
1. An anomaly in field theory occurs when a symmetry of the action or the corresponding conservation law, valid in the classical theory, is violated in the quantized version.
2. The breakdown of an internal symmetry (gauge symmetry) leads to an inconsistency of the quantum theory, while the breakdown of an external symmetry is not dangerous for the consistency of the theory.
3. Gravitation, regarded as a gauge theory, suffers from anomalies, including the Einstein anomaly, the Lorentz anomaly, and the Weyl anomaly.
4. The gravitational anomalies can be calculated using the method of dispersion relations, which is a less familiar but useful approach in quantum field theory.
5. The dispersion relation approach is an independent and complementary view of the anomaly phenomenon compared to the ultraviolet regularization procedures.
6. The method of dispersion relations has been successfully applied to calculate the gravitational anomalies, including the Einstein anomaly and the Weyl anomaly, in two dimensions.
7. The gravitational schwinger terms, which occur in the energy-momentum tensor, can be determined by the formfactor, which approaches a δ-function singularity at zero momentum squared in the zero mass limit.
8. The dispersion relation approach is equivalent to the n-dimensional regularization procedure of 't Hooft and Veltman, and the two approaches are linked by suitable substitutions.
9. The method of dispersion relations appears to be a promising approach for calculating gravitational anomalies and schwinger terms in higher dimensions as well.</summary>

<summary>
1. The Space Time Explorer and Quantum Equivalence Space Test (STE-QUEST) mission aims to study the cornerstones of Einstein's equivalence principle by measuring the gravitational red-shift experienced by highly accurate clocks in the gravitational fields of Earth or Sun, and differential accelerations of microscopic quantum particles. The mission will be launched in 2022/2024 as part of the European Space Agency's Cosmic Vision program.

2. The STE-QUEST payload consists of two instruments, the atomic clock and the atom interferometer, which will be used to test the universality of free fall and the weak equivalence principle. The mission will also include a precise orbit determination equipment and a ground segment with three ground terminals, each equipped with microwave antennas and optional optical terminals.
</summary>

<summary>
1. Pulsed high-frequency (HF) electromagnetic (EM) waves from transmitters on the ground are regularly used for sounding the density profile and drift velocity of the overhead ionosphere. This technique has been used in various experiments, including ionospheric modification experiments by a high-power HF radio wave at Platteville in Colorado. The experiments demonstrated the heating of electrons, deformation in ionosonde records, and excitation of spread F.

2. The interaction between powerful HF radio beams and the ionospheric plasma was first observed in 1970 in experiments conducted at Arecibo, Puerto Rico, using a scatter radar diagnostic technique. A decade later, it was found experimentally in Troms that strong, systematic, structured, wide-band secondary HF radiation escapes from the interaction region. This observation demonstrated complex interactions, including weak and strong EM turbulence, and harmonic generation.

3. Numerical simulations have become an important tool to understand the complex behavior of plasma turbulence. Examples include analytical and numerical studies of Langmuir turbulence and upper-hybrid/lower-hybrid turbulence in magnetized plasmas. In this letter, a full-scale simulation study of the propagation of an HF EM wave into the ionosphere is presented.

4. The simulation involves realistic scale sizes of the ionosphere and the wavelength of the EM waves. The results suggest that such simulations will become a powerful tool to study HF-induced ionospheric turbulence and secondary radiation on a quantitative level for direct comparison with experimental data. The simulation uses a vertically stratified ion number density profile and a constant geomagnetic field directed obliquely to the density gradient.

5. The EM wave is injected vertically into the ionosphere, with spatial variations only in the direction perpendicular to the geomagnetic field. The simulation neglects the EM field falloff, the Fresnel pattern created obliquely to the direction by the incident and reflected wave, and the influence on the radio wave propagation due to field-aligned irregularities in the ionosphere. The simulation uses a simple one-dimensional model and assumes a linearly polarized EM pulse.

6. The simulation results show that the EM pulse propagates without changing shape through the neutral atmosphere until it reaches the ionospheric layer. The initially linearly polarized EM wave undergoes Faraday rotation due to the different dispersion properties of the L-O and R-X modes in the magnetized plasma. The simulation also shows the reflection of the L-O and R-X modes at different altitudes and the mode conversion of the L-O mode into electrostatic Lang

<summary>
1. The Mott-Hubbard model of interacting bosons on a lattice has been used to describe superfluid Mott-insulator transitions in various systems, including Josephson arrays and granular superconductors. The model has been successfully applied to cold bosonic atoms in an optical lattice, which has rekindled interest in the Mott-insulator transition. The possibility of directly manipulating and testing the many-body behavior of a system of trapped bosonic atoms in an optical lattice is very attractive. Possible applications include the use of a Mott state of bosonic atoms in an optical lattice as a starting point to create controlled multiparticle entanglement.

2. The Mott-Hubbard model is described by a Hamiltonian that includes the kinetic energy of the bosons and the repulsive interaction between bosons on the same lattice site. The ratio of the onsite energy and the bandwidth forms the key parameter in the system, which can be easily controlled and varied by several orders of magnitude in optical lattices. Probing the system by taking absorption pictures to image the expansion patterns after a reasonable expansion time yields information about the momentum distribution of the state. This procedure was used to experimentally confirm the Mott transition in an optical lattice.

3. The Gutzwiller approach is based on an ansatz for the many-body ground state that factorizes into single lattice-site wavefunctions. However, this approach fails to describe the correct behavior of short-range correlations between different lattice sites, which are important for experimentally measurable observables. To get a satisfactory description of the short-range correlations, a perturbative approach is used to improve the Gutzwiller mean-field result. The perturbative corrections to the Gutzwiller result show important modifications to single-site observables as well as to the correlation function.

4. The perturbative corrections to the Gutzwiller result are particularly large in 1D, but get smaller with increasing dimension. The critical value is not modified within the present perturbative approach. The single-particle density matrix is of particular importance as it describes the correlation between the different lattice sites. The correlation function shows off-diagonal long-range order in the superfluid state, in contrast to the Mott-insulator phase where it decays exponentially.

<summary>
1. The paper discusses the classification and visualization of homogeneous isotropic cosmologies in multi-scalar models with an arbitrary scalar potential. The method involves augmenting the target space to a larger space of lorentzian signature, where the logarithm of the scale factor plays the role of time. This is reminiscent of mini-superspace models of quantum cosmology, where the scalar fields are moduli fields for extra dimensions. The lorentzian metric on the augmented target space is induced from the Wheeler-DeWitt metric on the space of higher-dimensional metrics.

2. The paper also presents a complete treatment of cosmological trajectories for simple exponential potentials, which are characterized by a sign and a coupling constant. The qualitative features of these trajectories are determined by the position and nature of any fixed points, which are of two types: the @xmath14 fixed point and the @xmath51 fixed point. The @xmath14 fixed point is a straight line in the augmented target space, which is also a geodesic. The @xmath51 fixed point is a straight line in the doubly-augmented target space, which is not a geodesic in the augmented target space.

<summary>
1. The authors of the paper discovered a faint and red star, LSPM J2322+7847, which is a candidate nearby low-mass dwarf, located at an angular separation of 5 arcseconds from the active and rapidly rotating G9V star HIP 115147. The faint star was identified with LSPM J2322+7847, a candidate nearby low-mass dwarf detected by the LSPM-North catalog. The original identification of this star as one with significant proper motion traces back to Luyten (1967), where it was reported as a magnitude 17 object with 17.99 mas/yr at a position angle of 17.99 degrees. The star was assigned the name LP12-90.

2. The authors present new photometry of HIP 115147, its known visual companion HIP 115147B, and LSPM J2322+7847, and obtain preliminary trigonometric parallax astrometry for the latter companion. The photometry was calibrated with an instrumental zero point term and a first-order airmass term. The calibration field was the standard field PG2213-006 from the NOMAD catalog. Additional photometric observations were subsequently obtained on UT 16 and 17 June 2007.

3. The photometric results are presented in Table 1, along with 2MASS photometry, proper motions from NOMAD, and parallax determinations. The estimated uncertainties in the J-band measures are 0.11 mag in the case of LSPM J2322+7847 and 0.04 mag for the HIP 115147 components. Since the August 2005 photometry indicated that LSPM J2322+7847 was most likely an M-dwarf at approximately the same distance as HIP 115147, it was added to the trigonometric parallax program at USNO's Flagstaff Station. A total of 66 acceptable CCD observations have been accumulated on this field, covering an epoch range of 1.65 years.

4. The authors discuss the possible young age and origin of this interesting triple system. The star HIP 115147 was identified with the bright X-ray source H2311+77, which led to the suggestion of RS CVN-type activity. <summary>
1. The universe is believed to be flat, and its energy density is dominated by dark energy, which causes the cosmic expansion to accelerate.
2. Researchers have tried to understand the connection between dark energy and particle physics, and one model, the mavans scenario, proposes that relic neutrinos could form a negative pressure fluid and cause cosmic acceleration.
3. In the mavans scenario, an unknown scalar field called the acceleron is introduced, and neutrinos are assumed to interact through a new scalar force, causing the neutrino mass to depend on its number density and change with the evolution of the universe.
4. The equation of state parameter and dark energy density also evolve with the neutrino mass, depending on the model of the scalar potential and the relation between the acceleron and the neutrino mass.
5. A supersymmetric version of the mavans scenario is proposed, where supersymmetry is broken in the hidden sector at the TeV scale and its effect is transmitted to the dark sector through gravity.
6. The model includes a chiral superfield in the dark sector, whose scalar component causes the present cosmic acceleration, and the right-handed neutrino superfield.
7. The model is able to avoid the instability of the speed of sound in the neutrino-acceleron fluid, and the evolution of the neutrino mass is consistent with cosmological observations.
8. The model provides a possible explanation for the origin of dark energy and the evolution of the neutrino mass, and it is a viable alternative to the cosmological constant model.

1. The quark gluon plasma (QGP) is a phase of quantum chromodynamics (QCD) where quarks and gluons are mostly liberated from their confinement within hadrons. This phase is currently being actively studied, and revealing its phase transition structure is a central aim of ongoing and future research. The QGP can be created in the early universe, at the core of super-dense stars, or in the initial stage of relativistic nucleus-nucleus collisions in heavy ion accelerators. The QGP is a new state of matter that can be created in the laboratory.

2. The QGP can be created at high temperature or high baryon density, and the critical temperature and baryon density required for the transition to take place are currently being studied. The QGP is expected to be a weakly interacting system, and perturbative methods can be used to describe its behavior. The asymptotic freedom of the QGP suggests two procedures for its creation: at high temperature or at high baryon density. The QGP is a complex system that requires a detailed understanding of its thermodynamic properties.

3. The thermodynamic properties of the QGP can be calculated using the Landau Fermi liquid theory, which describes the behavior of relativistic systems such as the QGP. The energy density of the QGP can be evaluated using the Landau Fermi liquid theory, and the results can be used to calculate other thermodynamic properties such as the pressure and entropy. The QGP is an ultra-relativistic system, and its thermodynamic properties can be calculated using the relativistic partition function. The QGP is a complex system that requires a detailed understanding of its thermodynamic properties.

4. The phase diagram of the QGP can be extracted by solving the equation of state, which relates the pressure and energy density of the system. The phase diagram can be used to determine the conditions under which the QGP is created, and it can be compared to lattice QCD calculations. The QGP is a complex system that requires a detailed understanding of its phase diagram. The phase diagram can be used to determine the conditions under which the QGP is created, and it can be compared to lattice QCD calculations.

<summary>
1. The authors propose a conformally symmetric model for strong interactions at low energies, which describes quarks and gluons as confined to an anti-de Sitter (ADS) universe with a finite radius in flat space-time.
2. They estimate the mass of a light scalar particle associated with confinement to be around 38 MeV, based on the average radius for quark-pair creation extracted from mesonic resonance data.
3. The authors suggest that this light scalar particle, which they designate as the @xmath30, could be a mini-universe filled with glue, forming a very light scalar glueball, and propose further investigation to confirm its existence.
</summary>

<summary>

1. The term "stochastic resonance" was introduced in the early 80s in the study of periodic advance of glaciers on Earth, and it refers to the effect of nonmonotone dependence of the response of a system on the noise when this noise is added to a periodic input signal. This phenomenon can improve the transmission of a signal by the addition of noise.

2. The problem of estimating a signal transmitted through a channel can be improved by adding noise, and the optimal level of noise is called stochastic resonance. The criterion applied to measure optimality of estimators are the Shannon mutual information or the Kullback divergence.

3. The Fisher information quantity has been proposed as a measure of optimality, and it can be maximized for certain noise structures. If there is only one global maximum, the corresponding noise level is the value for which we have stochastic resonance.

4. The authors study the problem of estimation and hypotheses testing for a model where a threshold and a subthreshold constant and non-negative signal are added with a noise that is a trajectory of a diffusion process. They propose two schemes of observations: observing only the proportion of time spent by the perturbed signal over the threshold and measuring the energy of the perturbed signal when it is above the threshold.

5. The authors propose two different estimators for the schemes and study their asymptotic properties. They show that the estimators proposed are asymptotically equivalent to the maximum likelihood estimators.

6. The authors also study a problem of testing two simple hypotheses for the model discussed in the previous section using the maximum a posteriori probability (MAP) criterion. They show that the decision rules for their model are similar to the one proposed by Chapeau-Blondeau in the i.i.d. setting.

7. The overall probability of error is a non-decreasing function of the signal, and the authors show that the effect of stochastic resonance can reduce sensibly the overall probability of making the wrong decision. This kind of behavior is not outlined in the work of Chapeau-Blondeau.

</summary>

<summary>
1. The order parameter in high-temperature superconductors (HTS) has been found to have mainly a d-wave pairing symmetry, which is confirmed by phase-sensitive measurements and thermal transport measurements. These measurements show that the predominant d-wave gap symmetry is present up to the superconducting critical temperature, with minor components smaller than 5% of that with the d-wave symmetry. The thermal conductivity measurements have also shown the predominance of this symmetry for the gap function. The fourfold oscillation in the thermal conductivity can be explained by considering both Andreev scattering of quasiparticles by vortices and Doppler shift in the energy spectrum of the quasiparticles.

2. The thermal conductivity measurements were performed on two single crystals of YBa2Cu3O7 (YBCO) at different temperatures and angles, with a magnetic field applied parallel to the CuO2 planes. The measurements show that the angle dependence of the longitudinal thermal conductivity changes above 15 K, with a minimum at 45° (field parallel to the heat current) and a maximum at high angles. The observed behavior can be well reproduced by a model involving Andreev scattering of quasiparticles by vortices and the two-dimensional Boltzmann transport equation for the thermal conductivity. The model assumes a d-wave pairing symmetry of the order parameter.

3. The numerical simulations using the Andreev scattering model and the two-dimensional Boltzmann transport equation for the thermal conductivity show a good agreement with the experimental results. The simulations reproduce the symmetry of the curves in the whole measured temperature range, and the calculated oscillation amplitude above 20 K increases up to 10 times that observed in the experiment. The factor used to fit the experimental oscillation amplitude is related to the inelastic scattering rate, which was not taken explicitly into account in the previous calculations. The temperature dependence of the inelastic scattering rate is given by the factor used to fit the experimental oscillation amplitude.

4. The thermal Hall angle measurements performed in the same YBCO twinned crystal show that the power law dependence obtained for the inelastic scattering rate is similar to that obtained for the longitudinal scattering rate assuming a d-wave pairing. The power law dependence is expected to be proportional to the density of quasiparticles, which is consistent with the simple two-fluid model. The spin-fluctuation scattering picture also predicts a power law dependence, but with a different exponent. The agreement between the experimental results and the model suggests that the mechanisms that influence the behavior

<summary>
1. Dehn surgery is an operation to modify a three-manifold by drilling and then regluing a solid torus, and it is used to study the properties of three-manifolds. The resulting three-manifold via Dehn surgery on a knot in a three-sphere along a slope is denoted by @xmath6.

2. Two Dehn surgeries along a knot with distinct slopes are called purely cosmetic if the resulting three-manifolds are oriented manifolds. The cosmetic surgery conjecture states that two surgeries on inequivalent slopes are never purely cosmetic.

3. The authors of the paper study purely cosmetic surgeries along knots in the three-sphere and show that for most knots, the resulting three-manifolds are not oriented manifolds for distinct slopes. They also provide a sufficient condition for a knot that admits no purely cosmetic surgery in terms of its Jones polynomial.

4. The main result of the paper gives a condition for a knot to have no purely cosmetic surgery, which is related to the second and third-order derivatives of the Jones polynomial. The authors also show that certain classes of knots, such as genus two knots and knots with a specific concordance invariant, do not admit purely cosmetic surgeries.

5. The authors use a surgery formula by Lescop, which involves a knot invariant that satisfies a crossing change formula. They also observe that this invariant is a finite type invariant of order 3 and use it to reformulate their main result.

6. The authors prove that the cosmetic surgery conjecture is true for all knots with no more than 10 crossings, except for a few exceptions. They also show that the conjecture is true for certain families of two-bridge knots and whitehead doubles.

7. The authors derive an explicit formula for the canonically normalized finite type knot invariant of order 3 for two-bridge knots in Conway forms. They use this formula to study the cosmetic surgery problem for two-bridge knots.

8. The authors apply their main result to study the cosmetic surgery problem for two-bridge knots of genus 2 and 3. They show that these knots do not admit purely cosmetic surgeries.

9. The authors also study the cosmetic surgery problem for the positive n-twisted whitehead double of a knot and show that it does not admit purely cosmetic surgeries for certain values of n. They also show that the untwisted whitehead double does not admit purely cosmetic surgeries for certain values of n.
</summary>

<summary>

1. Anomaly-mediated supersymmetry breaking (AMSB) models have attractive properties, including calculable soft supersymmetry breaking terms, real and flavor-invariant soft terms, and renormalization group invariance. However, AMSB models suffer from the problem of negative slepton mass-squared parameters, leading to tachyonic states. The original solution to this problem is to add a universal mass to the scalars.

2. The minimal AMSB model (MAMSB) has a parameter space given by m_0, m_3/2, A, and sign(μ). An alternative setup for AMSB is the hypercharged anomaly-mediation (HCAMS) model, which uses a similar setup but with a strongly warped hidden region. In HCAMS, the anomaly mediation can become the dominant source of supersymmetry breaking in the visible sector.

3. In HCAMS, the mass of the bino, the gaugino of U(1) gauge symmetry, can be the only soft supersymmetry breaking parameter not determined by anomaly mediation. Depending on its size, the bino mass can lead to a small perturbation to the spectrum of anomaly mediation or dominate the contribution from anomaly mediation. The HCAMS model should be easily distinguishable from the MAMSB model at the LHC if μ is not too large.

4. The HCAMS model predicts a negative mass squared for the sleptons and features relatively heavy squarks, while pure hypercharge mediation suffers from negative squared masses for stops and sbottoms and features relatively heavy sleptons. The combination of hypercharge and anomaly mediation leads to phenomenologically viable spectra for a sizable range of relative contributions. The HCAMS model has a parameter space given by m_0, m_3/2, A, and sign(μ).

5. In the HCAMS model, the soft supersymmetry breaking terms are of the form: m_1 = (3/5)g_1^2m_3/2, m_a = m_3/2, m_i^2 = -14(g_1^2 + g_2^2)m_3/2^2, and a_f = m_3/2. The wino and gluino masses receive a contribution from the bino mass at the two-loop level. The HCAMS model has been included in the ISASUGRA subprogram of the event generator ISAJET v7.79.

<summary>
1. The zero-range potential (ZRP) approach has been developed to widen the limits of traditional treatment by Demkov and Ostrovsky, and Albeverio et al. This approach allows for the possibility of obtaining an exact solution of the scattering problem. The ZRP can be represented as a boundary condition on the matrix wavefunction at some point or as a pseudopotential.

2. The Darboux transformation (DT) allows for the construction of exactly solvable potentials in a natural way. The DT can be defined on the basis of the covariance property of the Schrödinger equation with respect to a transformation of the wavefunction and potential. The DT can also be used to correct the ZRP model.

3. The DT can be used to dress the ZRP model, which improves its possibilities. The DT modifies the generalized ZRP (GZRP) boundary condition and creates a potential with arbitrarily disposed discrete spectrum levels for any angular momentum. The DT can also be used to add or remove poles of the matrix, which correspond to quasi-stationary states (resonances).

<summary>
1. The convection-diffusion model is a semi-linear parabolic partial differential equation that can be expressed mathematically, and it has remarkable applications in various branches of science and engineering, such as fluid motion, heat transfer, and astrophysics. The model has been solved numerically using various techniques, including finite element method, lattice Boltzmann method, and finite-difference scheme.

2. The proposed methods, including modified exponential cubic b-splines DQM, modified trigonometric cubic b-splines DQM, and mecdq method, transform the convection-diffusion equation into a system of first-order ordinary differential equations (ODEs) in time, which is solved by using SSP-RK54 scheme. The methods are found stable for two-space convection-diffusion equation by employing matrix stability analysis method.

3. The proposed solutions are more accurate in comparison to the solutions by various existing schemes, and are in good agreement with the exact solutions. The order of accuracy of the proposed methods for the convection-diffusion problem with Dirichlet's boundary conditions is cubic whenever the grid size is small, and otherwise it is super-linear, in space.
</summary>

<summary>
1. The study presents a robust sample of 19 bright submillimeter galaxies (SMGs) selected using SCUBA and MAMBO in the Lockman Hole region. The sample is expected to detect in well-matched radio imaging and minimize the possibility of spurious or anomalously bright sources. The study aims to determine the true fraction of radio drop-outs amongst SMGs and provide practical information such as the intrinsic positional uncertainty for SMGs in the absence of radio/IR counterparts. The sample is consistent with the spectroscopic redshift distribution determined by Chapman et al. (2005).

2. The study finds that the median redshift of the sample is 2.14, which is consistent with the spectroscopic redshift distribution determined by Chapman et al. (2005). The sample is also consistent with the predictions of the GALFORM semi-analytic model. The study suggests that the bright SMG population is readily amenable to study via radio-selected samples, down to a 850-μm flux density limit of 3.16 Jy. The study also notes that the dual-wavelength extraction performed here could potentially bias the sample against very-high-redshift sources that would only be detected at 1.2 mm.

<summary>
1. The authors present an analysis of the luminosity function (lf) of galaxies in the norris survey of the corona borealis supercluster, finding that the lf of local field galaxies agrees well with the lcrs, but the normalization of their local lf is roughly a factor of 1.6 higher than that of the stromlo/apm survey.
2. The authors observe evolution of the field galaxy lf within their sample, confirming previous redshift surveys, and find that the evolution is limited to the population of blue, star-forming galaxies, which becomes more luminous with increasing redshift.
</summary>

<summary>

1. The phenomenon of rapidity gaps in hadronic collisions has been observed at both the HERA and Tevatron colliders. These gaps are regions of pseudorapidity without hadronic activity, and they are widely attributed to the exchange of color singlet quanta between incident partons. The exchange of two gluons in a color singlet state is the simplest such model, and it has been used to predict the fraction of dijet events with rapidity gaps. The predicted gap fraction is of order one percent, which is consistent with the observed data.

2. The two-gluon exchange model predicts that the gap fraction should decrease with increasing jet transverse energy and pseudorapidity separation. However, the data from the Tevatron do not show this behavior, and instead suggest a slight increase in the gap fraction with increasing jet transverse energy. This casts doubt on the validity of the two-gluon exchange model, and suggests that non-perturbative effects may be important. The data are not yet precise enough to unambiguously distinguish between different scenarios.

3. The unitarized two-gluon exchange model is a more realistic description of the rapidity gap data, and it takes into account the non-perturbative effects of unitarity. The model predicts that the gap fraction should decrease with increasing pseudorapidity separation, and it is consistent with the data from the Tevatron. However, the model also predicts that the gap fraction should increase with increasing jet transverse energy, which is not observed in the data. The model's predictions are sensitive to the regularization parameters, which are not well-constrained by the data.

4. The unitarized two-gluon exchange model is able to describe the trend of the gap fraction with increasing pseudorapidity separation, and it is consistent with the data from the Tevatron. However, the model's predictions are not unique, and different choices of regularization parameters can lead to different results. The data are not yet precise enough to unambiguously distinguish between different scenarios, and further experimental and theoretical work is needed to clarify the situation. The unitarized two-gluon exchange model provides a more realistic description of the rapidity gap data than the two-gluon exchange model.

5. The unitarized two-gluon exchange model predicts that the color singlet exchange fraction should be strongly affected by the full unitarization, and it deviates from the expectations of the two-gluon exchange approximation

<summary>
1. The paper discusses various techniques for forecasting electric energy consumption, including time series, functional-based, and soft computing-based approaches.
2. The authors propose using an artificial neural network (ANN) approach to forecast electric energy consumption in the Gaza Strip.
3. The ANN model is trained using historical data from 1994 to 2011 and tested on data from 2012 and 2013.
4. The performance of the ANN model is evaluated using error criteria such as mean squared error (MSE), root mean squared error (RMSE), mean absolute error (MAE), and mean absolute percentage error (MAPE).
5. The results show that the ANN model can accurately forecast electric energy consumption in the Gaza Strip.
6. The ANN model is compared to other forecasting techniques, including time series and functional-based approaches.
7. The authors conclude that the ANN approach is a suitable method for forecasting electric energy consumption in the Gaza Strip.
8. The paper contributes to the existing literature on electric load forecasting and provides a new approach for predicting energy consumption in the Gaza Strip.
</summary>

<summary>

1. Low-mass X-ray binaries (LMXBs) are compact binaries where the primary is a compact object and the secondary is a low-mass star. The secondary transfers mass via Roche-lobe overflow, forming an accretion disk around the compact object that gives rise to the observed X-rays.

2. Most persistently bright LMXBs are neutron star systems that can be divided into two groups: the Z-sources and Atoll sources. Z-sources are usually the brightest LMXBs in X-rays and have mass accretion rates that reach the Eddington limit.

3. Atoll sources have lower accretion rates, typically 2 orders of magnitude lower than Z-sources, and their color-color diagrams usually consist of fragmented island-like regions. The main physical difference between Z-sources and Atoll sources is thought to be the strength of the neutron star magnetic field and their evolutionary history.

4. LMCX-2 is a persistent LMXB that shows the properties of a Z-source and is thought to be a neutron star system with an accretion rate around the Eddington limit. It is one of the most X-ray luminous LMXBs known, but its X-ray flux is rather low due to its extra-galactic nature.

5. The optical counterpart of LMCX-2 was identified as a blue star, but little is known about the system parameters of LMCX-2. The orbital period of LMCX-2 has been estimated to range from 6.4 hours to 12 days, but no periodic variability was detected in 6 years of MACHO data.

6. The authors of the paper used phase-resolved spectroscopy to detect a periodic signal in the radial velocity of the He II emission line, which they interpreted as the orbital period. They also detected narrow emission lines in the Bowen region, which they identified as coming from the irradiated surface of the donor star.

7. The authors created Doppler maps of the He II and Bowen regions, which showed a ring-like structure and a bright spot that appeared to have moved over night. They suggested that this bright spot could be an irradiated region that shows movement on a much longer timescale than the orbital period.

8. The authors constrained the system parameters of LMCX-2 using the narrow emission lines and the Doppler maps, but the constraints were not very tight. They speculated that LMCX-2 harbors a neutron star that is more massive

<summary>
1. The axial anomaly is a fundamental issue in quantum field theory, and its understanding is crucial for grasping the basic aspects of the theory. The anomaly problem has been analyzed deeply over the years, and various approaches have been developed to study it.

2. The Dolgov and Zakharov approach to the axial anomaly is based on the dispersion relation method, which provides a more direct treatment of the anomaly without evaluating divergent integrals. This approach shows that the anomaly is related to the chiral limit and can be interpreted as an infrared effect.

3. The axial anomaly can be derived by studying the properties of the amplitude in the infrared region, and it is connected to the presence of a non-conservation of helicity. The anomaly can be seen as a manifestation of the anomalous term present in the divergence of the axial current.

4. The cancellation of mass singularities in the decay rates for the radiative pion and Z decays occurs through different mechanisms, depending on the polarization of the outgoing lepton. In the case of the right-handed radiative decay, the mass singularities cancellation occurs through a mechanism different from the usual one of real and virtual compensation.
</summary>

<summary>

1. The problem of salient object detection, which involves identifying the most important object in a scene, has been a topic of interest in computer vision. This problem is challenging because it requires a model to prioritize objects for high-level processing, similar to human attention. The goal of salient object detection is to simulate the capability of human attention in prioritizing objects. This capability has several applications in recognition, image and video compression, and other areas.

2. A large number of saliency detection methods have been proposed in the past 7 years, but most of them have focused on scenes with single objects. These models have performed well on existing biased datasets, but it is unclear how they perform on complex cluttered scenes with several objects. The lack of suitable benchmark datasets and a widely-agreed objective definition of the most salient object has hindered the development of more advanced models. This paper aims to provide solutions to these problems.

3. The authors propose a simple baseline salient object detection model that involves two steps: selecting objects to process and segmenting the object area. The first step uses a fixation prediction model to find spatial outliers in scenes that attract human eye movements and visual attention. The second step uses a superpixel segmentation algorithm to segment the object area. This model is designed to be simple and computationally efficient.

4. The authors exhaustively compared their model to 8 state-of-the-art methods, which have been shown to perform well on previous benchmarks. The comparison was done using two widely-adopted metrics: precision-recall curve and receiver operating characteristics (ROC) curve. The results showed that the authors' model performed well on the msra-5k dataset but struggled on the bruce-a and judd-a datasets. The authors attribute this performance drop to the models' inability to segment the wrong object as the most salient one.

5. The authors also analyzed the interplay between saliency detection, fixation prediction, and object proposal generation. They suggest that these models depend on each other and that correctly predicting where people look is critical to knowing which object is the most salient one. The authors also propose that labeled objects in scenes can help study how objects guide attention and eye movements.

6. The authors' model separates detection from segmentation, which allows it to be used for other purposes, such as segmenting interesting or important objects. The model can also be used as an active observer by incorporating a top-down fixation selection strategy. The authors believe that their model can be used as a baseline for

<summary>
1. The paper discusses the construction of a decorated topological quantum field theory (tqft) in 3 dimensions, called Heegaard Floer theory, which was constructed by Ozsváth, Szabó, and others.
2. The theory involves counting pseudoholomorphic disks and triangles in symmetric products of Riemann surfaces, and it can be used to detect exotic smooth structures on 4-manifolds with boundary.
3. The authors aim to give a combinatorial procedure for calculating the ranks of the maps induced by two-handle additions in Heegaard Floer theory.
4. They show that any two-handle addition can be represented by a nice triple Heegaard diagram, which is a Heegaard diagram with a single basepoint and a set of points in the surface.
5. The authors also discuss the construction of a nice triple Heegaard diagram for a cobordism from a 3-manifold to itself, which involves adding a two-handle along a knot in the 3-manifold.
6. They show that the Heegaard Floer map induced by a cobordism from a 3-manifold to itself can be decomposed into maps induced by one-handle, two-handle, and three-handle additions.
7. The authors review the definitions of the Heegaard Floer maps induced by one-handle and three-handle additions, which involve the action of the group H_1(M) on the Heegaard Floer invariants.
8. They also discuss the naturality of the Heegaard Floer maps, which is the property that the maps induced by different Heegaard diagrams for the same 3-manifold are isomorphic.

<summary>
1. The paper aims to extend the results of Yetter on the deformation theory of associative algebras and poset-indexed diagrams to arbitrary pasting diagrams of @xmath0-linear categories, @xmath0-linear functors, and natural transformations.
2. The authors establish that obstructions are cocycles in a family of pasting diagrams sufficient to imply the result in general, using a method developed heuristically by Shrestha.
3. The paper also makes explicit a point overlooked in the statements and proofs of theorems 8.2 and 8.3, that the cochain maps constructed in those theorems depend on choices of association for 2-dimensional compositions in the pasting diagram.
4. The authors use the cochain maps to give explicit examples of deformation complexes associated to various shapes of commutative pasting diagrams, and show that cochain maps induced by two different associations of the 2-dimensional composition are not actually equal, but only chain homotopic.
5. The paper concludes by stating a theorem that encapsulates Shrestha's polygonal method for showing that all obstructions are cocycles, provided certain conditions are met, and provides figures to establish the result for specific cases.
</summary>

<summary>
1. The main goal of physics is not only to calculate observable quantities but also to understand the underlying physical picture responsible for a given phenomenon, which can be achieved by selecting essential degrees of freedom.
2. In the case of crystals, the fundamental degrees of freedom are ions in the lattice, electrons, and the electromagnetic field, but to understand electric conductivity and heat capacity, it is more effective to work with "heavy electrons" and phonons.
3. Similarly, in Quantum Chromodynamics (QCD), the full nonquenched QCD on the lattice becomes too complicated at the scale of 1 GeV, and the spontaneous breaking of chiral symmetry is the most important QCD phenomenon in this case.
4. The chiral symmetry breaking leads to the appearance of the octet of pseudoscalar mesons and the dynamical mass of valence quarks, which are called constituent quarks, and the coupling of constituent quarks and pseudoscalar goldstone bosons has a specific form.
5. The chiral constituent quark model provides a unified description of both nonstrange and strange baryon spectra in good agreement with phenomenology, and the short-range repulsion in the nn system is induced by the same short-range part of chiral interaction that produces hyperfine splittings in baryon spectroscopy.
</summary>

<summary>

1. The invention relates to novel calcium phosphate-coated implantable medical devices and processes of making same. The unique calcium-phosphate coated implantable medical devices minimize immune response to the implant. The coated implantable devices have the capability to store and release one or more medicinally active agents into the body in a controlled manner. This invention has the potential to save millions of lives annually around the world.

2. Cardiovascular stents are widely used in coronary angioplasty procedures to enlarge coronary arteries and thereby allow better blood circulation. Typically this is accomplished by a balloon angioplasty procedure wherein a contracted stent, usually in the form of a metallic mesh tube, is moved into the site of blood vessel narrowing along a guide wire. Once the stent is in place an internally situated balloon expands it radially. After expansion the balloon is deflated and removed from the vessel while the stent remains expanded in place.

3. The placement of metallic stents often leads to harmful side effects. A relatively large proportion of patients (up to half of the population, according to some statistics) experience an immune response to the implanted stent called inflammatory restenosis, and other negative effects, which lead to a re-narrowing of the vessel. This typically requires repeat surgical treatment within 1-2 years of the original balloon angioplasty operation. The mechanisms that lead to restenosis and other immune responses associated with the implantation of a medical device are initiated by damage to the vessel lining during the surgical procedure.

4. The most common surface modification of implanted medical devices is the application of a thin polymer film coating. These coatings are frequently impregnated with medically active agent(s) such as antibiotics, anti-inflammatory agents and other, more complex drugs. These medically active agents are released from the coating through leaching to the arterial wall and the blood stream, often aided by dissolution of the carrier film. Typically, biodegradable polymers such as polylactic acid, polyglycolic acid, and others, frequently in combination with heparin and other anti-thrombogenic agents, are selected in such drug delivery systems.

5. In the past, polymeric materials have been used for drug delivery control and have enjoyed substantial clinical success for certain drug systems. Unfortunately, even biodegradable polymers, although more bio-friendly than the native metallic surface, are still recognized by living tissue as foreign objects. Therefore the bio-degradation process is frequently accompanied by inflammatory response of the tissue. In some critical applications, such as

<summary>
1. The present invention relates to nerve conduits for the regeneration of peripheral nerves, which can be used to treat peripheral nerve injuries (PNI) that can lead to a lifelong disability, such as paralysis. The most frequent causes of PNI include motor vehicle accidents, gunshot wounds, stabbings, and birth trauma. Current treatments for nerve repair, such as end-to-end suturing and application of autograft or allograft biological tissue, suffer from several limitations.

2. The present invention provides a fabricated implantable nerve guidance conduit (NGC) with an integrated spiral structured porous sheet decorated with surface channels and electrospun fibers. The NGC has superior mechanical strength compared to NGCs in the prior art, along with integrated multiple channels, stable aligned fibrous layers, good inter-cell communication, and high surface/volume ratios within the NGCs. The NGC also has chambers at the distal and proximal ends to provide additional space for fitting nerve stumps.

3. The NGC of the present invention comprises a three-dimensional (3-D) spiral structured porous sheet having two chambers at the ends thereof. The spiral structure includes a highly porous polycaprolactone (PCL) sheet, which may be formed as a spiral-wound sheet using known methods and decorated with surface channels on a surface of the spiral wound sheet. The NGC also has a dense layer of randomly-oriented fibers on the outside of the spiral structure to improve the mechanical properties of the NGC.

4. The NGC of the present invention has been tested in a 10 mm Sprague Dawley (SD) rat sciatic nerve defect to evaluate the effect of nanofibers on peripheral nerve regeneration through porous spiral NGCs. The results showed that the NGC with nanofibers (T-S-AF) had significantly greater cell proliferation than the NGC without nanofibers (T). The NGC with nanofibers also showed improved functional recovery and nerve regeneration compared to the NGC without nanofibers.

</summary>

<summary>
1. The invention is related to seat base support assemblies for furniture, particularly sinuous band seat spring assemblies, and aims to provide a new and improved rail connector that combines the features of conventional helical spring connectors while eliminating their undesirable features. The rail connector is designed to produce spring torsioning and dynamic uplift at the back rail through kinetic energy stored within itself.

2. The invention provides two forms of rail connectors: a first form using pre-stressed, close-wound coil springs with attachment arms, and a second form using a pre-stressed, cantilever spring configuration. The first form can be modified to have a leverage-amplified torsioning capability, while the second form can be used with a sinuous spring band having leverage-amplified torsioning incorporated within it.

3. The rail connectors of the invention can be used to connect various types of seat base support means to the frame rails, including wire grids, chord-rubber webbing, and flat steel bands, providing them with dynamic uplift adjacent the back rail. The connectors can also be used to connect de-arced sinuous spring bands, pre-loading them upwardly to provide a dynamic uplift that would otherwise not be present.

1. The present disclosure is directed to an anvil assembly for use with a surgical stapling device, particularly a circular surgical stapling device. The anvil assembly includes a stabilizing collet positioned to prevent damage to the anvil assembly. The collet is supported within a longitudinal bore defined by the anvil shaft.

2. The anvil shaft includes a plurality of flexible legs that flex outwardly in response to insertion of a trocar of a surgical stapling device into the anvil shaft. The flexible legs cooperate to define a longitudinal bore that is dimensioned to receive the trocar. The bore extends from the proximal end of the flexible legs at least partially into the tubular portion of the anvil shaft.

3. The anvil shaft may include a plurality of splines positioned about the anvil shaft to properly orient the staple cartridge in relation to the anvil plate of the anvil assembly. The anvil shaft may also include one or more stabilization rings positioned about the anvil shaft to provide added stability to the anvil assembly. The stabilization ring may be formed integrally with the anvil shaft or secured to the anvil shaft using a fastening technique.

4. Each of the flexible legs defines a longitudinal channel with an adjacent leg, and each longitudinal channel includes an enlarged cutout or hole formed at the distal end. The holes are configured to secure a collet within the longitudinal bore of the anvil shaft. The collet is substantially cylindrical and defines a longitudinal bore that is dimensioned to receive the trocar.

5. The collet includes a distal portion with a plurality of cantilevered fingers, each of which includes a protrusion that is dimensioned and configured to be received in a respective one of the holes formed in the anvil shaft. The collet is positioned within the longitudinal bore defined by the anvil shaft and extends from a distal end of the flexible legs towards the proximal end of the flexible legs. The collet is secured within the longitudinal bore of the anvil shaft in a position that does not interfere with outward flexing of the flexible legs.

6. The trocar includes a pointed distal end and an enlarged proximal portion that defines a shoulder. When the trocar is inserted into the longitudinal bore of the anvil shaft and the longitudinal bore of the collet, the enlarged proximal portion of the trocar engages a proximal end of the flexible legs of the anvil shaft to urge the flexible legs outwardly. When the enlarged prox

<summary>

1. The present invention relates to a container of a blender, particularly to a set of high-speed blades mounted inside the lower portion of the container. The usage of blender has become popular today, and the configuration structure of a blender is mainly a set of rotatable blades disposed inside the container to mix the ice cubes, vegetables, and fruits until they become liquid. In early phases, the container of the blender was made of glass, but it had several drawbacks such as breakage and expansion due to temperature changes.

2. The container made of reinforced plastic was also not ideal as it resulted in nicks and debris being mixed into the liquid, leading to poor hygiene conditions. The inventors of the present invention encountered these problems and provided a metal lining (cylindrical member) to shield the inner wall of the receptacle. This metal lining was patented in TW580,899 and U.S. Pat. No. 6,786,440.

However, the whirlpool brings the rough and long fibers to the outer circle in contact with the inner wall by centrifugal force.

4. The present invention aims to provide a container of the blender that comprises a cup and a lining disposed inside the cup. The lining is formed as a shield inside the cup, and a number of teeth are projected from the inner wall of the lining for grinding the fibers of vegetable and fruit. The lining can be selected from metal, glass, or a material with a hardness rather rigid than the acrylic cup.

The teeth can be arranged in parallel with one another or in a crossed or columned shape. The lining can be made of metal, glass, alloy, or non-alloy material.

6. The container of the blender includes a cup and a rigid lining mounted inside the cup. The lining is shaped as a half-mask, and several vertical ribs are protruded from the inner wall of the cup. The vertical stopper members are formed on the obverse side of the wall of the lining, and hollowed troughs are formed on the reverse side of the wall of the

No. 13/080,754, titled GARNISH PICK, filed Apr. 6, 2011, which is a Non-Provisional of and claims priority to U.S. Provisional Patent Application Ser. No. 61/321,291, titled GARNISH PICK, filed Apr. 6, 2010. The entire contents of these applications are incorporated herein by reference in their entirety for all purposes.
