2. The conventional method of continuously coloring the anodic coating of aluminum strips or wires has defects such as poor weatherability and fading over time. The present invention aims to overcome these defects by providing a method for continuously conducting first an anodic oxidation and then an electrolytic coloring of an aluminum strip or wire.

3. The anodic oxidation bath composition used in this invention is usually an aqueous solution of 10 to 55% sulfuric acid, and the thickness of the oxide film formed on an aluminum strip or wire is controlled by the amount of electric current passing per unit area. The bath temperature also influences the thickness of the oxide film but is sufficient in the range of room temperature to about 40° C.

4. The electrolytic coloring bath contains an aqueous solution of at least one of a nickel salt, a cobalt salt, a copper salt, a tin salt, and selenious acid, and the d.c. current passes from the anode to the anodic oxidation bath through the coloring electrolyte and the aluminum strip or wire. The control of the amount of the electric current in each route is accomplished by adjusting the rheostats.

5. The apparatus of this invention can produce continuously and with a low cost aluminum strips or wires having colored oxide films or layers thereon superior in weatherability or fade resistance. The industrial value of the apparatus is quite high, and various changes and modifications can be made therein without departing from the spirit and scope thereof.
</summary>

<summary>
1. The present invention relates to a process of producing transgenic plants transformed on a chromosome, and it also relates to a process of screening nucleotide sequences for a desired phenotype in plants. The invention further relates to transgenic plants and to libraries of plants or plant seeds obtained or obtainable according to the processes of the invention. The invention also relates to vectors for these processes and to plants or plant cells transformed therewith.

2. The current methods of stable plant transformation usually employ direct or Agrobacterium-mediated delivery of pre-engineered DNA fragments into plant cells. However, these methods are time-consuming, inflexible, and restricted to simple excision of desired DNA fragments. The methods are also limited in combinatorial diversity, as they are restricted to simple manipulations with a limited number of known genes and regulatory elements.

3. The inventors of this invention have overcome the low efficiency of site-specific recombination by using transiently delivered T-DNA for in planta engineering of a sequence of interest for integration into a chromosome. The efficiency of achieving stable integration events is comparable to that for a standard Agrobacterium-mediated transformation. The overall process of the invention is of sufficient efficiency for enabling routine applications of the process of the invention.

4. The process of the invention allows for the production of transgenic plants or plant cells that are stably transformed on a chromosome with a DNA sequence of interest, whereby said DNA sequence of interest derives from at least two different vectors. The DNA sequence of interest contains sequence portions from at least two of said at least two different vectors, said sequence portions being necessary for expressing said function of interest from said DNA sequence of interest.

5. The invention provides a process of producing transgenic multi-cellular plants or plant cells stably transformed on a nuclear chromosome with a DNA sequence of interest and capable of expressing a function of interest from said DNA sequence of interest. The process comprises providing plant cells or plants with at least two different vectors by Agrobacterium-mediated delivery, and selecting plants or plant cells expressing said function of interest. The process also comprises providing plants or plant cells with a mixture of a primary vector and a set of secondary vectors, and selecting transformed plants or plant cells expressing a function of interest.

6. The assembly of a DNA sequence of interest in planta from precursor vectors can be greatly facilitated by the presence of helper sequences that are preferably absent in the assembled DNA sequence of interest. These helper sequences may end up in recombination products that do not contain said DNA sequence of interest. The helper

<summary>
1. The present invention relates to a swash plate type compressor for compressing refrigerant gas, where a fluorocarbon coating is applied to the swash plate facial surfaces and ends to reduce frictional wear on the components. The coated swash plate may be made from lower cost alloy materials while maintaining durability and efficiency.

2. The coating is a heat curable, cross-linked coating comprising a polyfluoro elastomer bonded directly to the aluminum, a lubricious additive, and a load bearing additive. The polyfluoro elastomer is dissolved in a liquid to aid in applying the coating onto a surface.

3. The lubricious additive is selected from a group of materials that provide reduced friction in applications that use little or no oil (dry), such as carbon black, molydisulfide, cesium fluoride, lithium fluoride, and mixtures thereof. The load bearing additive is selected from a group of materials that provide high hardness and durability in dry conditions.

4. The coating process of the present invention does not require a high surface finish on the swash plate, and a roughened surface on the swash plate surfaces is preferred to give the coating a mechanism to mechanically attach to the swash plate. The surface roughening may be formed on the swash plate surfaces by abrasive grit blasting with alumina oxide, electro-discharge machining, honing, or rough machining.
</summary>

<summary>
1. The present invention relates to organic polymers suitable for use in anti-reflective coatings on semiconductor devices, and methods for preparing them. These polymers can be used to form a layer that prevents the reflection of light from lower layers coated on a semiconductor chip during photolithography processes. The polymers of the present invention can be used in processes for forming submicro-patterns using 193 nm (ArF) and 248 nm (KrF) light beams in the manufacture of semiconductor devices. The polymers are designed to facilitate light absorption at wavelengths of 193 nm and 248 nm by having groups that absorb light strongly at both wavelengths.

2. The polymers of the present invention can be prepared in accordance with reaction equations 1, 2, and 3, which involve the reaction of polyhydroxystyrene resin, poly(styrene-acrylate) resin, and novolac resin with diazonaphthoquinone halide in the presence of an amine. The reaction temperature is preferably between 50 and 80° C. The polymers can be dissolved in an organic solvent to form an anti-reflective coating composition. The composition can be used to form an anti-reflective coating on a semiconductor silicon wafer by filtering, coating, and hard-baking the solution.

<summary>
1. The invention relates to a white, flame-retardant, UV-resistant, thermoformable, oriented film made from a crystallizable thermoplastic, with a thickness of 10-350 μm, and good optical and mechanical properties.
2. The film comprises at least one white pigment, one flame retardant, and one UV absorber, and can be produced cost-effectively.
3. The film is suitable for outdoor applications and/or critical indoor applications, and can be used for various purposes such as interior decoration, exhibition stands, and promotional items.
4. The film can be produced using a process that involves extrusion, longitudinal and transverse stretching, and heat-setting, and can be recycled without difficulty and without pollution of the environment.
5. The film has excellent UV resistance, flame retardancy, and thermoformability, and can be used to produce complex moldings without predrying.
6. The film can be produced in various thicknesses, including 50 μm, 17 μm, and 20 μm, and can be used for a wide range of applications, including construction, lighting, and advertising.
</summary>

<summary>

1. The present invention relates to an improved method for producing 1,1,1-trifluoroethane (143a) by continuous gas phase hydrofluorination of 1,1-difluoro-1-chloroethane (142b) using heterogeneous catalysis. The process involves passing 142b and hydrogen fluoride (HF) through a catalyst bed in a reactor at specified conditions for reacting. The 143a product is then purified, and byproduct HCl and unreacted HF are removed by various methods. The process can be carried out using 142b as a feed and 1,1-dichloro-1-fluoroethane (141b), 1,1,1,3,3-pentafluorobutane (365) or HCl as a co-feed.

2. The catalyst used in the process is a chromium salt, supported or unsupported, and can be any chromium salt, supported or unsupported. The catalyst can also be a supported or unsupported co-catalyst, such as nickel, cobalt, manganese, and zinc. The preferred supports are Al2O3 and fluorided Al2O3. The process can be carried out at a temperature between 30° C. and 400° C., preferably between 30° and 280° C.

3. The molar ratio of HF to 142b is a critical factor in the process, and ideally, this ratio should be very close to 1 to minimize the need for downstream separation. However, at low HF ratios, non-selectives (unwanted by-products) are formed, including vinylidene fluoride (1132a), vinylidene chlorofluoride (1131a), and vinylidene chloride (1130a). These olefins are undesirable in the final product and must be either destroyed or removed from the reaction product. The HF/142b ratio should be greater than 1:1 to avoid olefin formation.

4. The reactor effluent contains 143a, HCl, and HF, and the conversion is generally in excess of 99.5%. The acids can be scrubbed out by caustic washing or recovered by distillation. If distillation is used, a pressure distillation is needed to recover HCl with conventional refrigeration. The boiling point of HCl at 130 psig is -26° F.

5. The adiabatic process of the invention provides a method

<summary>

1. The invention relates to an improved process for the deacylation and desulfurization of a compound having the formula: ##STR3##. This process employs hypophosphorous acid to improve product yield and reduce the yield of unwanted impurities. The use of hypophosphorous acid results in the formation of H2S by-product rather than sulfur. This makes it easier to remove the by-product from the reaction zone.

2. The compound in question is a pyrazolotriazole, which is useful as a magenta coupler for photographic products. However, it is difficult to synthesize and only a few synthetic routes are known. One of the preferred synthetic routes involves the preparation of triazolothiadiazines and their subsequent desulfurization. This process is not straightforward and generates unwanted impurities.

3. The triazolothiadiazines can be prepared in two ways: by reaction of 4-amino-5-mercapto-3-substituted(R)-1,2,4-triazoles with alpha-haloketones, or by reaction of 2-hydrazino-5-substituted-(R')-1,3,4-thiadiazines with acyl halides and subsequent dehydrative ring closure. Both the triazoles and the thiadiazines are readily available from thiocarbohydrazide. The desulfurization of the triazolothiadiazines to pyrazolotriazoles is a two-step process. The first step involves a ring contraction reaction, and the second step involves hydrolysis and desulfurization.

4. The ring contraction reaction is usually clean and does not render any problems except for long reaction times. However, the subsequent reactions are not straightforward and generate unwanted impurities, including elemental sulfur and sulfur-containing organic impurities. These impurities can interfere with subsequent reaction steps and are detrimental to the product. The use of hypophosphorous acid in the process of this invention reduces the amount of these impurities.

5. The use of hypophosphorous acid in the process of this invention has several advantages, including the reduction of unwanted impurities and the increase of product yield. The process is also straight-forward and economical to carry out. The use of hypophosphorous acid results in the formation of H2S by-product, which is readily removable from the reaction zone. This makes the process more efficient and easier to control.

6

<summary>
1. The invention relates to a method and apparatus for forming fiber mixtures from a plurality of fiber types by sequentially taking partial quantities from different fiber lots. The method aims to eliminate the disadvantages of the known processes, such as fiber residuals and non-optimal homogeneity.

2. The known processes involve positioning a plurality of fiber bales of different types next to each other and moving a carriage past the bales to take partial quantities. However, this method has several disadvantages, including the removal of a predetermined quantity from a plurality of fiber bales, which can lead to fiber residuals and non-optimal homogeneity.

3. The invention provides an improved method of forming fiber mixtures by measuring the entire momentary quantity of each stored fiber lot before the first pass or each pass. The determined partial quantity is then continuously removed only from the measured fiber lot.

4. The method according to the invention involves measuring the fiber bales individually before each opening pass, calculating the partial quantity, and then removing the calculated fiber quantity from each fiber bale during the pass. This process is repeated in a predetermined number of bale opening passes.

5. The invention also relates to an apparatus for performing the method, which includes a bale opener, a quantity measuring device, and a control device. The control device controls the mode of operation of the opener as a function of the signals transmitted by the quantity measuring device.

6. The apparatus may include a height-measuring arrangement, a light barrier, or an electromechanically operating sliding potentiometer as the quantity measuring device. The control arrangement may have a control apparatus and a computer that determines the precise partial quantities to be removed and controls the fiber removing operation.

7. The control device may have a timing relay that predetermines a maximum period to ensure that the partial quantity from each stored fiber lot is removed not later than at the end of the predetermined period. The control apparatus may control the displacement of the transporting device on which the bale opener is mounted.

8. The method according to the invention can be performed in three different ways, including removing the partial quantity in a predetermined number of passes, removing the partial quantity not later than at the end of a predetermined period, and setting different fiber removal periods for different fiber bales.
</summary>

<summary>
1. The present invention is directed to a method and apparatus for forming bias laid, non-woven fabrics, where the yarns in at least two of the layers of fabric are laid at an angle of from 30° to 150° to the long axis of the fabric. The yarns in the various layers are neither knitted, nor woven, but are held together by stitching through the layers, or by other external means, such as adhesive bonding. The invention provides for the formation of bias laid fabrics where all of the yarns in a given layer are parallel to each other. The parallelism in a given layer is achieved without complex machinery.

2. The apparatus for forming the bias laid, non-woven fabric includes a pair of parallel conveyors, each carrying a series of equidistantly spaced needles, and yarn carriers that move back and forth between the conveyors. The yarn carriers carry a plurality of individual, equally spaced yarns, and the number of yarns in a given linear dimension need not equal the number of needles in the same linear dimension. The rake systems, which are synchronized with the conveyors, yarn carrying means, and bonding mechanism, are associated with the needles formed on the conveyors to achieve greater assurance of parallelism of the yarns. The fabric formed in accordance with the present process is generally used in the formation of structural parts, such as airplanes, and is wrapped around a mold or laid into a particular position before being impregnated with a resin.
</summary>

<summary>
1. The present invention relates to weft insertion in a multiple-color air jet loom, and more particularly to a method of and an apparatus for inserting a selected weft thread with a weft carrying force appropriate for the selected weft thread. The invention aims to provide a method and an apparatus for inserting different weft threads in and through warp sheds in a multiple-color air jet loom. The apparatus includes a source of air under pressure, a regulator, and a subtank. The subtank is connected to dedicated subnozzles and common subnozzles.

2. The subnozzles are divided into groups along the warp shed and spaced at different intervals for the groups to produce combined air streams of varying pressures. The air pressure is controlled by a regulator and a subtank, which supplies air under different pressures to the subnozzles. The subnozzles are selectively operated dependent on the weft thread to be inserted for carrying the selected weft thread with a weft carrying force suitable for that weft thread. The different weft carrying forces may be produced by varying the interval of time in which air is ejected or by varying air ejecting forces.

3. The air ejecting forces are produced by a selective combination of different pitches of subnozzles, different effective cross-sectional areas of nozzle orifices of the subnozzles, different distances of the nozzles from the warp shed, different angles at which the subnozzles are directed to the warp shed, and different pressure under which air is supplied to the subnozzles. The on-off valves may be selectively actuated by a mechanical cam device operable in synchronism with the rotation of a main shaft of the loom. The mechanical cam device may comprise a control cam mounted on a valve control shaft. The control cam makes one third of a full rotation when the main shaft of the loom makes one complete revolution.

4. The weft insertion apparatus shown in FIGS. 4 and 5 has a source of pressurized air, a pair of regulators, and accumulator tanks. The regulators reduce the air pressure to a suitable degree, and the reduced air pressure is stored in the accumulator tanks. The pressure in the accumulator tank is selected to be low for the insertion of the thinner weft thread. The pressure in the accumulator tank is selected to be higher than that in the accumulator tank for the insertion of the thicker weft thread.

5. The air jet loom employing two different weft

<summary>
1. The present invention relates to a bast fibre yarn obtained through spinning bast fibres, and a process of making thereof. The process involves health preserving bast fibres, opening, cleaning, and carding the health preserved bast fibres, drawing the carded bast fibres into bast fibre strips, and then health preserving the bast fibre strips. This process allows for the production of bast fibre yarn with a low end breakage rate.

2. The invention also includes a process for blended spinning bast fibres and other fibres, which involves health preserving bast fibres, blending the health preserved bast fibres with other fibres, opening, cleaning, and carding the blended fibres, drawing the carded blended fibres into multi-fibre strips, and then health preserving the multi-fibre strips. This process can be used to produce multi-fibre yarn with a low end breakage rate. The invention also includes various examples of the process, including the use of different types of bast fibres and blending ratios.

3. The examples of the invention demonstrate the effectiveness of the process in reducing the end breakage rate of bast fibre yarn and multi-fibre yarn. For example, Example 1 shows that the end breakage rate of jute fibre yarn can be reduced to 200 times per hour for each machine when the yarn is 12 s in fineness. Similarly, Example 7 shows that the end breakage rate of bast fibre yarn can be reduced to 151 times per hour for each machine when the yarn is 12 s in fineness.
</summary>

<summary>
1. The present invention provides a method and apparatus for measuring and removing rotational variability from the nip pressure profile of a covered roll in a nip press, allowing for a more accurate display of the nip pressure profile.
2. The invention uses multiple sensors circumferentially spaced at various cross-directional positions along the sensing roll to cancel the effects of rotational variability, and the average of measurements of two or more sensors spaced apart circumferentially can provide a good measurement of the actual pressure being developed.
</summary>

<summary>
1. The invention is a combination electrical cord support and holder for articles, particularly useful for ironing boards. It supports the electrical cord of an electric iron above the ironing surface and holds an article, such as a spray starch can or a beverage container. This invention aims to provide a convenient and safe way to iron while having necessary items nearby.

2. The apparatus consists of a releasable clamp, a flexible cord support, and a detachable article holder. The clamp is C-shaped and has a pair of leg portions that extend from an end portion, with one leg portion engaging the ironing surface and the other located below the underside of the ironing surface. The clamp also has a movable jaw that secures the apparatus to the ironing board.

3. The flexible cord support has a first rod, a second rod, and a coiled spring resilient section. The first rod has a cord receiving end, and the second rod has a lower end with a foot pivotably received by an opening defined by a brace and the upper leg portion of the clamp. The foot has a tab that is retained by a detent on the brace to hold the cord support in a raised position.

4. The detachable article holder has a lower circular hoop and a pair of support bars, with an upper hoop having tangs that are detachably received by openings in a mounting brace. The article holder also has vertical supports that provide lateral support for an article. The apparatus has an extension portion for mounting a female electrical outlet, which can receive the plug from the iron.

<summary>
1. The invention relates to buttonhole controlling devices for a sewing machine, aiming to provide a device that can be effective regardless of the type of material being sewn to cause buttonhole stitching to close without overlap. The device includes a foot pad that attaches to a presser bar and a travelling assembly with an initial position defined by oppositely acting springs. The travelling assembly moves with work fed during the sewing of a buttonhole and includes a slidable member that may be positioned by a button for which a buttonhole is to be sewn. This slidable member carries a tab to actuate a tripping lever on the machine during movement of the assembly.

2. The buttonhole controlling device of the invention includes a foot pad that attaches to a presser bar, and a travelling assembly consisting of a work engaging shoe and a plate. The shoe includes rails that form guide channels for the side edges of the pad to permit relative sliding of the travelling assembly and foot pad. The work engaging shoe and plate are separable parts held in assembled relationship with a wall on the plate extending upwardly through a slot in the shoe. The shoe includes a fixed part with an anchor element that is formed with a base defining a shallow cavity loosely accommodating a coiled end of a flat spring.

3. The anchor element includes an upstanding abutment with a 'V' notch adapted to engage and center one side of a round button, and a post at the end of the base remote from the 'V' notch. The shoe is provided with a gaging element that is formed with an upstanding abutment and a set of rails shaped to overlie and slide on the rails of the shoe. The gaging element may be shifted away from the anchor element to the extent permitted by the abutment engaging the post. A tab for use in actuating the tripping lever is provided on the rail of the gaging element.

4. An adjustable stop is provided for use in actuating the tripping lever on the rail of the shoe. The position of the actuating tab with respect to the adjustable stop may be varied in accordance with the size of the button inserted between the 'V' notches. The adjustable stop includes a screw having a threaded connection with a boss affixed with a bracket to the rail. A knob is provided on the screw to facilitate turning by an operator.

5. When buttonholes are to be sewn with the device, the button for use with such buttonholes is first placed between the 'V

<summary>
1. The invention relates to an apparatus for treating a dyed or printed textile web with a liquid, such as a washing or rinsing solution, and aims to provide an improved apparatus that can adequately effectuate washing or rinsing without maintaining the textile web in a stacked configuration.
2. The apparatus comprises a conveyor, a liquid applicator, a suction device, and a dwell stretch, with the conveyor including an endless sieve belt for transporting the textile web along a predetermined horizontal path.
3. The dwell stretch is designed to conduct the textile web in a spread-out condition and in a single layer through at least one dwell loop, allowing the action time of the applied liquid on the substances to be removed from the fabric to be lengthened.
4. The apparatus can have a compact construction, and the suction device is advantageously disposed near the point of return of the web to the sieve belt, causing the textile web to adhere to the belt and to be entrained thereby.
</summary>

<summary>
1. The dry cleaning machine of the present invention provides an air flow system for bringing ambient air into the access opening whenever the door is opened, which is exclusive of the air recirculating system and substantially reduces exhausting the residual solvent vapors from the tubs. A separate intake fan and duct is provided with the duct interposed between the access opening of the machine housing and the open ends of the interior tubs. The intake fan is energized and a normally closed valve is opened in response to the access door being opened, allowing air to be drawn into the access opening and directly into the interposed duct. This minimizes the loss of solvent vapors to the atmosphere.

2. The machine also includes a refrigeration system for condensing the vapors in the condenser box and maintaining the liquid solvent in the storage tank at a predetermined temperature to minimize vaporization. The system is energized when the thermostat within the tank exceeds a predetermined limit, and the refrigerant flow path includes a compressor, condenser, accumulator, filter, and sight-glass. The refrigerant is directed into the evaporator coils in the storage tank to cool the solvent, and during the dry portion of the cycle, the refrigerant is directed into the evaporator coils in the condenser housing to condense the solvent vapors. The system also includes a control mechanism that allows the proprietor to alter the timer operation to provide a modified dry operation for drying the filter cartridges.

<summary>
1. The present invention involves an initial quench chamber and a continuous two-dimensional slot across the entire machine width, which produces a linear plane of filaments with substantially constant filament distribution across the machine width.
2. The system uses a single source of air for both quenching and drawing the filaments, eliminating the need for two separate air sources and associated equipment, and reducing noise levels and energy consumption.
3. The invention allows for easy control of filament denier and web formation uniformity, and can produce fine continuous filaments with deniers under 5, suitable for various applications such as nonwoven webs, pillow and cushion stuffing, and industrial filtration.
</summary>

<summary>
1. The sewing machine according to the first embodiment includes at least one detecting portion, a processor, and a memory. The detecting portion is configured to detect an ultrasonic wave that has been transmitted from a transmission source, and the processor is configured to identify a position of the transmission source of the ultrasonic wave based on information pertaining to the ultrasonic wave that has been detected by the detecting portion.

2. The sewing machine can accurately identify the specified position by detecting the ultrasonic wave using the plurality of receivers and calculating the specified coordinates E based on the transmission timing T1 and the detection timings T2. The sewing machine can start sewing on the work cloth in the specified position.

3. In the second embodiment, the receivers are provided on an embroidery unit that can be attached to and detached from the bed of the sewing machine. The embroidery unit includes a body portion and a carriage, and the receivers are provided on the upper surface of the carriage.

4. The sewing machine can calculate the specified coordinates E more precisely and perform sewing on the work cloth by detecting the ultrasonic wave using the receivers and calculating the specified coordinates E based on the detection timings T2 of the receivers. The sewing machine can control the X axis motor and the Y axis motor to move the embroidery frame such that the position of the specified coordinates E on the work cloth matches the needle drop point.

<summary>
1. The present invention relates to fabrics and textiles, particularly cellulosic fabric or textile materials, and provides a preparation for application onto a cellulosic fabric or textile material to enhance utility. The preparation comprises a blended mixture of wool particles or wool powder and a binding agent, where the functional additive is carried by the wool particles. The wool particles or wool powder is preferably of macrofibril size or below.

2. The invention also provides a method of preparing a preparation for application onto a cellulosic fabric material comprising wool as a functional additive carrier. The method involves pulverizing wool to obtain ultrafine wool powder of macrofibril size and forming an ultrafine wool suspension using the ultrafine wool powder. The method may also comprise the step of pulverizing the wool powder into a suspension of ultrafine wool particles by ultrasonic crushing.

3. The invention further provides a method of preparing a preparation comprising bamboo fibre as a functional additive. The method involves pulverizing bamboo fibre to obtain coarse bamboo powder, adding a wetting agent and bamboo powder into water to form a suspension, and pulverizing the coarse bamboo powder in the suspension into ultrafine bamboo powder. The ultrafine bamboo powder is then mixed with ultrafine wool powder and a binding agent to form a finishing paste.

4. The treated fabric exhibits improved properties such as ultraviolet protection, moisture management, wrinkle recovery, and anti-bacterial properties. The ultraviolet protection ability of the fabric is evaluated in terms of ultraviolet protection factor (UPF) value, which is determined by following the testing method of AATCC 183 standard. The treated fabric provides excellent ultraviolet protection, moisture management, wrinkle recovery, and anti-bacterial properties, making it suitable for various applications.
</summary>

<summary>
1. The present invention relates to an automatic quilting machine for use in stitching individual selected patterns into a large fabric such as a bedspread or quilt. The machine comprises a large metal frame on which the fabric is stretched, a sewing machine head mounted on a cross beam, and a quilting table that can move in the X-direction, Y-direction, or any X-Y combination direction.
2. The machine is controlled by two separate computers, one for the sewing machine function and one for the quilting table movement, which allows for independent programming and reprogramming of each function without affecting the other. This simplifies the process of making adjustments or changes to the stitch or pattern, reducing the effort and time required to reprogram the entire system.
</summary>

<summary>
1. The present invention relates to methods of making nonwoven fabrics, particularly a method of manufacturing a two-sided nonwoven fabric exhibiting a three-dimensional image.
2. The production of conventional textile fabrics is a complex, multi-step process, whereas nonwoven fabrics are produced directly from the carding process.
3. Nonwoven fabrics have commonly been disadvantaged compared to conventional textiles, particularly in terms of resistance to elongation, but hydroentangled fabrics have improved properties.
4. The present invention contemplates a two-sided, three-dimensionally imaged nonwoven fabric comprised of at least three layers, with a support layer or scrim acting as a fiber distribution control layer.
5. The fabric is formed by hydroentanglement on a three-dimensional image transfer device, which defines three-dimensional elements against the precursor web.
6. The precursor webs are formed into a three-dimensionally imaged nonwoven fabric by hydroentanglement on a three-dimensional image transfer device, with the first fibrous matrix displaced into the three-dimensional topography.
7. The present invention contemplates that the fluid-pervious support layer or scrim be any suitable material, including wovens, knits, open mesh scrims, and/or nonwoven fabrics.
8. The fabric of the present invention may comprise apertures, which may be of various shapes and sizes, and may extend through one or more layers of the fabric.
9. The material of the present invention may be utilized in the construction of numerous home cleaning, personal hygiene, medical, and other end-use products where a three-dimensionally imaged nonwoven fabric can be employed.
</summary>

<summary>
1. The invention is a device for feeding a strip of material into a sewing machine and sewing it onto a cut of fabric. This device ensures a continuous operation, making it possible to sew relatively stiff strips of material, and being insensitive to disturbances. The device includes a stop that can be moved into the feed path of the strip and retracted from the feed path after being contacted by the strip.

2. The stop is carried by a doubled arm lever member and is part of a control means including a control switch and a setting means for adjusting the position of the stop. The stop is mounted for being displaced by a setting means in the form of an air cylinder and substantially perpendicularly to the feed motion of the workpiece. The limits of the setting motion of the stop can be adjusted by displaceable stops.

3. The device operates as follows: the stop is moved into the feed path of the strip, and the leading edge of the strip butts against the stop, causing pivoting of the lever and determining the sewing position of the strip. The stop is then retracted from the feed path, and the sewing machine is started again to perform the sewing operation. The device ensures a continuous operation and makes it possible to sew relatively stiff strips of material.
</summary>

<summary>

1. The present invention relates to a knitting method and a knit fabric for linking a rope- or tape-shaped knit fabric in various parts of clothing, such as the collar of a sweater, neck rope portion of a tanktop, lower end portion of baseball stockings, and neck rope portion of an apron. The invention aims to provide a connective knitting method of two tape-shaped knit pieces that is employed in a knitting procedure of a tape-shaped knit piece and a tape-shaped knit fabric knitted thereby. The method comprises steps of knitting two tape-shaped knit pieces by a flat knitting machine possessing at least a pair of front and rear needle beds.

2. The flat knitting machine used in this invention has multiple knitting needles disposed on needle beds laid out in a V-form in a side view in a manner free to move and slide back and forth, with the rear one of the needle beds formed movably in the lateral direction. The machine is capable of knitting two pieces of tape-shaped knit fabric in a specified length by arbitrary needles in different ranges across the boundary in the longitudinal direction of one of the needle beds. The machine is also equipped with a carrier for feeding the knitting yarn.

3. The two pieces of tape-shaped knit fabric are knitted with a boundary between them in the longitudinal direction on either of the front and the rear needle beds. When both the moving side knit fabric and fixed side knit fabric are knitted to a specific length, the rear moving needle bed is moved one pitch to the left in the drawing from the reference position of the blocks. The loop of the moving side knit fabric is transferred to the knitting needles of the moving needle bed.

4. The loop stopped on the knitting needle of the moving needle bed is confronted with the loop of the knitting needle of the adjoining fixed needle bed. The loop on the knitting needle of the moving needle bed is transferred to the loop of the knitting needle of the fixed needle bed and overlaid, and a new loop is formed thereby knitting a bind-off. The carrier for feeding the knitting yarn moves to the left of the knitting needle of the fixed needle bed.

5. The new loop formed on the knitting needle of the fixed needle bed is transferred to the knitting needle of the moving needle bed. The moving needle bed is racked one pitch to the right from the reference position, and the loop of the knitting needle of the moving needle bed is transferred to the knitting needle of the fixed needle bed. Three loops are stopped on the knitting needle of the fixed needle bed.

6. The knitting

<summary>
1. The invention relates to a flexible traction element, a production line for embedding stranded cables in a flexible thermoplastic plastics material, and a method for embedding at least one stranded cable in a flexible thermoplastic material. The traction element comprises at least one stranded cable made of a material guaranteeing tensile strength.

2. The stranded cables are made by winding at least six peripheral strand cords around a central strand cord, and the strand cords consist of individual fibres or wires of a material guaranteeing tensile strength. The flexibility of a conventional stranded cable can be considerably increased by coating the core strands with a flexible thermoplastic plastics material layer.

3. The production line for sheathing at least one stranded cable with a flexible thermoplastic plastics material comprises an extruder with a thread guide for the stranded cables and at least one matrix, which can be adjusted with and in relation to one another, individually, in a plane angled with respect to the cable plane. The stranded cables run through the extruder and the outlet opening of the matrix, lying on one plane.

4. The method for embedding at least one stranded cable with a plastics material-coated core strand according to the invention involves unwinding the stranded cables, degreasing and/or pretreating them to improve the adhesion of the plastics material jacket, preheating them to a temperature of about ±20° C. of the melting temperature of the flexible thermoplastic plastics material sheathing the core strands, and sheathing them in the extruder with the liquefied plastics material.

5. The production line for producing band-shaped traction elements begins at a system with reels for unwinding the flexible stranded cables and ends with a storage roller for winding the band-shaped traction elements. The production line includes various devices such as an extruder, pressure rollers, a cooling trough, and a control apparatus for controlling the thickness of the traction element.
</summary>

<summary>
1. The invention relates to a new and useful rotary hook arrangement for a lockstitch sewing machine, aiming to improve the sewing properties and reduce the needle thread tension. The rotary hook arrangement includes first and second cams arranged on respective sides of a projection of the bobbin housing of a rotatable hook for controlling the rotation of the bobbin housing.

2. The known rotary hooks have limitations, such as impediment of the thread movement during the guiding of the needle thread loop around the bobbin housing, which results in increased needle thread tension. The impediment occurs due to the holding means which prevent co-rotation and reverse rotation of the bobbin housing being arranged in the vicinity of the stitch hole.

3. The invention provides a rotary hook arrangement where the holding means are arranged so that they hinder the guiding of the needle thread loop and the pull-back occurring after its maximum expansion as little as possible. This is achieved by locating the holding means on the loop cast-off side of the bobbin housing.

4. The needle thread loop can be expanded totally unhindered until its maximum expansion is reached, and then it is pulled back by the thread take-up lever without touching the front cam. The slight impediment of the thread movement caused by the bending of the spring rod can be eliminated completely.

5. The capsule release device gives the bobbin housing a rotational impulse counter to the direction of hook rotation, creating a narrow gap between the rear side face of the shoulder and the spring rod. This allows the needle thread loop to slip through the thread passage gap entirely unhindered.

6. The rotary hook arrangement is simple in design, rugged in construction, and economical to manufacture, making it an improvement over conventional rotary hooks. The invention provides a lockstitch sewing machine with a rotary hook that has especially jerk-free and low friction motion of the needle thread loop.
</summary>

<summary>

1. The invention is a method for producing silicon-based nanowires and composites from four-component inks comprising a liquid silane, a polymer, an accelerant, and a solvent. The four-component inks can be used to produce silicon-based nanowires and composites with targeted conductivities and structural stability. The invention also includes five-component inks comprising a liquid silane, a polymer, a solid phase, an accelerant, and a solvent. The five-component inks can be used to produce silicon-based nanowires and composites with additional properties such as photoactivity or reactivity.

2. The liquid silane used in the invention can be a cyclosilane, such as cyclohexasilane (Si 6 H 12 ), or a linear or branched silane, such as Si n H 2n or Si n H 2n+2. The polymer used in the invention can be a poly(methyl methacrylate) or a polycarbonate. The accelerant used in the invention can be a polyhydropolysilane, which accelerates the polymerization of cyclohexasilane. The solvent used in the invention can be toluene, xylene, cyclooctane, or dichloromethane.

3. The invention includes a method for producing silicon-based nanowires and composites using electrospinning. The method involves combining a liquid silane, a polymer, an accelerant, and a solvent to form a viscous solution. The solution is then expelled from a nozzle or drawn from a film and exposed to a high electric field, resulting in the formation of continuous fibers that are deposited onto a substrate. The deposited fibers can then be transformed using thermal processing or laser processing.

4. The invention also includes a method for producing silicon-based nanowires and composites using a five-component ink. The five-component ink includes a liquid silane, a polymer, a solid phase, an accelerant, and a solvent. The solid phase can be a particulate, photoactive, or reactive compound. The method involves combining the five components to form a viscous solution, which is then expelled from a nozzle or drawn from a film and exposed to a high electric field, resulting in the formation of continuous fibers that are deposited onto a substrate.

5. The invention includes a method for producing an anode material using the silicon-based nanowires and composites produced by the invention. The method involves combining the silicon-based

<summary>
1. The present invention is directed to an arrangement for the control of thread tension in a spool creel having several spool holders each provided with a brake rotor working with a braking element that is adjustable by a tensioning lever carrying a roller.
2. The arrangement has a plurality of controllers that are simultaneously settable by fluid pressure, each coupled to a different corresponding one of the spool holders.
3. Each controller has a brake rotor and an adjustable, tension responsive, braking element coupled to the brake rotor.
4. The arrangement also has a tensioning lever coupled to the braking element for biasing it, which has a roller adapted to engage and be biased by the threads.
5. The tensioning lever is operable to occupy an angular position dependent upon thread tension and weight.
6. A biasing arrangement is adapted to be activated by fluid pressure and connected to the tensioning lever, each of the tension levers being simultaneously settable by the fluid pressure.
7. The biasing arrangement operates in addition to the weight force on the tensioning lever, whereby the thread tension is also altered.
8. The force generated by the biasing arrangement can be centrally set so that the thread tension can be determined for the entire creel.
9. The braking force throughout the entire creel can be increased when the warping machine served by the creel is shut off, allowing for a quick braking action.
10. The biasing arrangement can be formed by a piston/cylinder assembly, which can readily follow the swinging movement of the tensioning lever by changing their length.
</summary>

<summary>

1. The present invention relates to a sewing machine detector for detecting the position of a sewing needle and the speed of the sewing machine. The detector is integral with the drive and control elements of the sewing machine. The conventional sewing machine drive system includes a sewing machine, motor, belt, needle section, control circuit section, detector, and power indicating light. The detector is used to control the sewing machine.

2. The conventional detector includes a detecting section, an optical fiber cable, a photoelectric translation processing module section, and electrical connectors. The detecting section includes a sewing machine shaft, a shaft of the detecting section rotated in engagement with the sewing machine shaft, and needle UP and DOWN position detecting reflective discs. The optical fiber cable includes a detecting section, an optical fiber cable, a photoelectric translation processing module section, and electrical connectors. The photoelectric translation processing module section includes electronic parts such as light emitting and receiving devices and a signal processing circuit.

3. The conventional detector has several disadvantages, including the influence of static noise due to the friction of a fabric to be sewn, malfunction, and unstable sewing machine operations. The reflective discs must withstand constant vibration during the operation of the sewing machine. The bearings supporting the shaft of the detecting section may be worn, causing the shaft to vibrate and the optical axes to change. This results in an inability to receive predetermined signals.

4. The conventional detector also has the disadvantage of expensive optical fibers being necessary to prevent the above-described problems. The curvature radius of the optical fibers is large, resulting in a decrease in the light transmitting percentage and a deterioration in efficiency. The optical fibers are flexed, imposing significant stress on the fibers. This stress may cause the optical fiber supporter to fracture.

5. The conventional apparatus also includes a power indicating light having a light emitting diode and lead wires run through a cable. The power indicating light is supplied by the control circuit section through regular lead wires run through the cable. However, high frequency welders generate high frequency electromagnetic waves that can act as antennas and receive the electromagnetic waves, generating an electromotive force.

6. The present invention aims to overcome the disadvantages of the conventional apparatus by providing a low-price detector for a sewing machine that is durable despite the detrimental effects of vibration. The detector includes a thinner and more compact detecting section. The detector minimizes stress imposed on the optical fibers by minimizing the curvature of the optical fibers. The power indicating light does not electrically interfere with the operation of the detector and controller.

7. A preferred embodiment

<summary>
1. The present invention aims to simplify the process for the continuous production of viscose rayon yarns with a high degree of whiteness.
2. The process involves completing the coagulation of the yarn, washing it with water having a non-alkaline pH, and then drying and possibly finishing it.
3. The washing process is critical in reducing the amounts of certain elements retained on the yarn, such as total sulphur, elemental sulphur, and metal ions like iron, zinc, and lead.
4. The water used for washing should have a pH between 4.0 and 5.5 and be free from cations in amounts higher than certain specified levels.
5. The process can be carried out with spinning speeds not lower than 90 m/min, and the washing and coagulation completion stages can be done within specific time frames.
6. The invention achieves a high degree of whiteness in the finished yarn, which is higher than that commonly accepted, through a simplified and economical process.
</summary>

<summary>

1. The invention is a continuation-in-part of a patent application Ser. No. 594,455 filed Mar. 29, 1984, now abandoned. The problem encountered when bleaching pulp with oxygen is attempting to wash the pulp after the oxygen stage. The oxygen entrained in the pulp mat reduces the vacuum on the vacuum washer and mixes with the wash water to form foam. This reduces the vacuum in the washer and prevents the chemicals and water from passing through the mat.

2. There have been a number of proposals for deaerating the pulp before the washer. One proposal is to use a 'Deculator' process which is described by Mac Gregor. The Deculator process involves the rapid acceleration and spraying of stock into a long 6-foot diameter stainless steel receiver. This system involves expensive equipment, including vacuum systems and vacuum vessels.

3. Another system is described in Sethy, U.S. Pat. No. 4,209,359 issued Jun. 24, 1980. In this system, the slurry is agitated by a radial flow impeller which imparts a substantially radial flow to the slurry. Several types of impeller are shown. This system is also large and expensive.

4. Other large degassing chambers are shown in Roymoulik, et al. U.S. Pat. No. 3,832,276 granted Aug. 27, 1974, and in Richter, U.S. Pat. No. 3,963,561 granted Jun. 15, 1976. These are large expensive systems utilizing large tanks which must be built to withstand pressure. The Richter patent describes a large pressure vessel. These systems are not suitable for small-scale deaeration.

5. The inventors decided that there was a need for a small deaeration tank which may be at either atmospheric pressure or under low pressure or vacuum. The tank should be the same diameter as an oxygen reactor so that it could be placed on top of the reactor and be supported by the reactor. It would have no moving parts, so there would be no need for motors to be mounted on or near the tank. A closed tank would allow steam or oxygen to be recovered.

6. The deaerator is a small tank having an inlet pipe, an outlet, and a tangential swirl inducing inlet pipe. The locations and sizes of these elements provide optimum deaeration. The swirl inducing fluid is the filtrate from the washer after the oxygen bleach

<summary>
1. The invention relates to biomimetic tendon-reinforced (BTR) composite materials with improved properties, including high out-plane stiffness and strength-to-weight ratio, designed using a function-oriented material design (FOMD) process.
2. The FOMD process employs topology optimization to optimize material distribution and achieve optimal structural performance, which has been applied to various areas, including structural designs and material designs.
3. The BTR composite structure consists of stuffer members, tendon elements, and panels, which can be arranged in various configurations, including flat, curved, and complex shapes, and can be embedded in a matrix material for enhanced structural performance.
4. The invention has been extended to develop a composite armor with added ceramic layers for blast and ballistic protection, and has been applied to various fields, including aerospace, marine, and vehicular body parts.</summary>

<summary>

1. The invention relates to a load-limiting device for dissipating energy during a dynamic event, such as an earthquake. The device is designed to be placed in a braced frame structure and can undergo plastic deformation to limit the loads levied on the structure. The load-limiting device can be easily removed and replaced after plastic deformation with a new non-plastically deformed device. This allows for the structure to be preserved from extensive damage after a dynamic event.

2. The load-limiting device is designed to provide biaxial support for the braced frame structure and can dissipate energy in the structure. The device can be constructed of a plastic material or a metal-based elasto-plastic material. It can be attached to a connection means that couples the device to the brace in the braced frame structure. The device can have an opening for attachment of the connection means to the brace.

3. The load-limiting device can be used in various structural applications, including buildings, vehicles, aircraft, furniture, and roller-coasters. It can be used to dissipate energy during a dynamic event by further yielding of the material in the plastic hinges of the device. The device can be designed to have elasto-plastic stress-strain properties similar to low-carbon steels. It can be manufactured with a plurality of load capacities depending on the strength requirements of the device.

4. The load-limiting device can be checked after a dynamic event of moderate to severe intensity to determine if it has undergone plastic deformation. An indicator means can be used to indicate whether plastic deformation has begun on the device. The indicator means can be a brittle coat of material, a mechanical device, or an electronic sensor. The device can be removed from the structure if plastic deformation is detected and replaced with a new device to preserve the structure from further damage.

</summary>

<summary>
1. The present invention relates to a bedroom cabinet that is designed to provide a flophouse facility comprising a number of individual rooms on the floor of an existing building. The bedroom cabinet is composed of a dual construction comprising an outer casing and an inner casing, which provides excellent mechanical strength.

2. The outer casing is formed to be flat, and the inner casing is positioned within the outer casing to form a clearance. This clearance can be used to house electric devices, wirings, or other components without projecting them from the outer periphery of the cabinet.

3. The bedroom cabinet has a front panel with an opening for an exit, and the inner casing is provided with boxes for accommodating devices such as an interphone or a radio receiver. The boxes are formed to be projected outwardly, but they do not project within the cabinet or from the outer periphery of the outer casing.

4. The bedroom cabinet also has a ceiling panel with a sound-proofing effect, and the bottom panel is formed with a rim to fix a mat. The inner casing is connected and fixed to the outer casing by seals or a fit-in type groove.

5. The bedroom cabinet can be assembled by fitting the inner casing into the lower outer casing and then fitting the upper outer casing on top. The flanges of the upper and lower outer casings are brought into abutment with each other and held by a clip member, and an ornamental web is wound around the flanges to cover the exit.
</summary>

<summary>
1. The present invention relates to a portable, temporary guard rail support for use in the erection of a safety barrier or fence at sites under construction, such as office buildings, high-rise apartments, or the like. The guard rail support comprises a substantially flat bottomed base plate, an upright column, at least one guard rail support bracket, a kick board retaining flange, an angular brace, and a safety tie-off ring. The guard rail support is designed to provide a safe work area for workmen working at dangerous heights.

2. The guard rail support can be used to construct a safety barrier by locating a plurality of supports at spaced intervals about the perimeter of a ground surface under construction and attaching the baseplate of each support to the ground surface using suitable fasteners or anchors. The upper and lower safety rails may be individually placed and secured within the brackets of adjacent supports, extending completely about the perimeter of a floor under construction. The guard rail support and associated guard rail assembly of the present invention reduces or eliminates the liability which may result from inadequately re-installed guard rails.
</summary>

<summary>

1. The present invention pertains to the stimulation of crude oil reservoirs to enhance production using a combination of pulsed power electrohydraulic and electromagnetic methods. The invention provides a method and apparatus for recovery of crude oil from oil-bearing soils and rock formations. The method involves using pulsed power to generate acoustic and coupled electromagnetic-acoustic vibrations that can cause oil flow to be enhanced and increase the estimated ultimate recovery from reservoirs.

2. The stimulation of crude oil reservoirs to enhance oil production from known fields is a major area of interest for the petroleum industry. One of the single most important research goals in fossil fuels is to recover more of the hydrocarbons already found. At present, approximately 66% of discovered oil is left in the ground due to the lack of effective extraction technology for secondary and tertiary Enhanced Oil Recovery (EOR).

3. Methods that are widely used for the purpose rely on the injection of fluid at one well, called the injection well, and use of the injected fluid to flush the in situ hydrocarbons out of the formation to a producing well. In one mode of secondary recovery, a gas such as CO2 that may be readily available and inexpensive, is used. In other modes, water or, in the case of heavy oil, steam may be used to increase the recovery of hydrocarbons.

4. The present invention differs from all of the prior art in several ways. It uses a coupled process of direct EH acoustic vibrations that propagate outward into the formation from one or more wells, and electromagnetically-induced high-frequency acoustic vibrations. This is significantly different from the prior art which relies on acoustic vibrations only, or a combination of acoustic vibrations and low-frequency AC or DC electrical stimulation.

5. The invention includes the use of EM pulse sources that do not generate a direct acoustic shock pulse like the plasma shock effect caused by the spark gap in the electrohydraulic device defined by Wesley. These pulse sources replace the conventional spark gap discharge device defined by Wesley with a single-turn magnetic coil that produces a magnetic pulse with no acoustic pulse effect.

6. The invention also includes the use of directional focusing and shaping devices that will cause the acoustic pulse to travel only in specific directions. This reflector cone allows the operator to aim the pulses from one or multiple wells so that they can effect the specific portion of the formation where stimulation is desired.

7. The invention includes the use of a multi-level discharge device that allows sequential firing of several sources in one well in a time sequence that is optimized to allow continuous

<summary>

1. The present application is a continuation-in-part of a co-pending U.S. patent application Ser. No. 12/684,479, which was filed on Jan. 8, 2010. The contents of the co-pending application are incorporated herein by reference in their entirety. The application relates to a wave anchor soil reinforcing connector and method. The connector is used to reinforce an earth mass in combination with a facing element.

2. Retaining wall structures that use horizontally positioned soil inclusions to reinforce an earth mass in combination with a facing element are referred to as Mechanically Stabilized Earth (MSE) structures. MSE structures can be used for various applications including retaining walls, bridge abutments, dams, seawalls, and dikes. Basic MSE technology involves a repetitive process by which layers of backfill and several horizontally placed soil reinforcing elements are sequentially positioned one atop the other until a desired height of the earthen structure is achieved. The soil reinforcing elements are typically made of a welded wire grid.

3. The soil reinforcing element generally includes a welded wire grid having a pair of longitudinal wires that are disposed substantially parallel to each other. The longitudinal wires are joined to a plurality of transverse wires in a generally perpendicular fashion by welds or other attachment means at their intersections, thus forming the welded wire grid. In some applications, there may be more than two longitudinal wires. The longitudinal wires may have lead ends that generally converge toward one another and terminate at a wall end.

4. The wall end of each soil reinforcing element may include several different connective means adapted to connect the soil reinforcing element to a substantially vertical facing, such as a wire facing, or concrete or steel facings constructed a short distance from the standing earthen wall. Once appropriately secured to the vertical facing and compacted within the backfill, the soil reinforcing element provides tensile strength to the vertical facing that significantly reduces any outward movement and shifting thereof. The longitudinal wires of the soil reinforcing element may extend several feet into the backfill before terminating at corresponding reinforcing ends. Where added amounts of tensile resistance are required, longer soil reinforcing elements are required, thereby disposing the reinforcing ends even deeper into the backfill.

5. The splice for a soil reinforcing element may include a first wave plate defining one or more first transverse protrusions configured to receive and seat a corresponding number of transverse wires of the soil reinforcing element, and a second wave plate defining one or more second transverse protrusions configured to receive and seat a corresponding number

<summary>
1. The present invention relates to a novel design for a plow blade that provides a fluid passage and points of fluid ejection, which is produced with basic manufacturing processes allowing efficient production. This design includes a multiple component assembly that allows for rebuilding a blade by replacing a portion of the blade that may be worn. The fluid passage is defined by providing a small gap between the front surface of the blade and the rear surface of the leading edge section.

2. The fluid pressure at a certain point along the blade's length can be varied by extending the fluid tube to terminate at a position towards the bottom of the critical high friction area. The number of leading edge sections and the location of the stitch welds can also be adjusted to tailor a plow for a specific application. This allows for a nearly infinite variety of configurations in an economic manner.
</summary>

<summary>
1. The present invention relates to a building system, specifically stucco type cavity wall construction techniques and resultant consumables, subassemblies, assemblies, etc.
2. The invention aims to provide a building system that allows panels of greater than 2.4 meters in height to be created and/or greater than 4 meters width to be created without movement joints.
3. The system consists of a frame or substructure, battens supported from and fixed to the frame or substructure, a first mesh attached to the battens, a second mesh supported at least in part by a plaster matrix, and the plaster matrix applied as more than one layer.
4. The plaster matrix penetrates the first mesh, interposes both meshes, attaches to the second mesh, and covers the second mesh.
5. The system also includes regional reinforcement, such as metallic mesh, and lattice-like periphery defining members.
6. The invention provides a method of in situ formation of a reinforced plaster panel as cladding of a support structure, comprising fixing battens to the support structure, preparing for the panel creation, applying plaster into and onto the inner mesh, overlaying the second and levelling coat with a mesh, and applying a third plaster coat.
7. The system includes various components and consumables, such as battens, flashing tape, powder-coated aluminium Z flashings, and MCL StuccoRite NZ 660 Multicoat Cement Plaster.
8. The system is designed to meet the performance requirements of the Building Code, including structural integrity, durability, spread of fire, and external moisture.

1. The invention relates to a safe with a valuables receiving chamber and a door that is received in and completely removed from the open upper end of the chamber.
2. The safe has a liner with laterally extending grooves that receive the edges of bar members, which are then coupled together in spaced relation upon assembly.
3. The door is secured to the liner by a lockbolt that engages a notch in the liner, and safety bolts are provided to reinforce the door assembly against lateral movement.
4. The safe can be formed using a cast-in-place concrete construction, or it can be formed entirely of metal, and it can be modified to include additional features such as a firecap or steel blocks in place of safety bolts.
</summary>

<summary>
1. The invention provides a fluid measuring technique that more accurately measures the fluid pressure in the part of the formation at the same depth, elevation, or vicinity of the pressure sensor, by isolating the pressure sensor in a borehole and creating a fluid connection between the formation and the pressure sensor.
2. The technique involves cementing a conduit with a filter at its bottom end in the borehole, pressurizing the conduit to clear it of cement grout, and then displacing the cement grout to form a fluid connection between the formation and the filter.
</summary>

<summary>

1. The present invention relates to a jointing structure in vehicle traveling path joints and the like having an expansion function, which is adaptable for applications of various tire configurations different in tire diameter, ensures high slip resistance to tires, permits less occurrence of tire fall-in and/or stuck-in situations, and is easy to be given the maintenance. The jointing structure comprises more than one step provided face to face at the coaxially built traveling path ends with an expansion gap between, more than one elastic member respectively mounted inside the above more than one step, and a joint block mounted on the above more than one elastic member across the above expansion gap. The elastic members are desirably of a material that is hard to be deformed vertically and vice verse easy to be deformed horizontally in a soft manner. The present invention employs elastic members mainly consisting of laminated rubber.

2. The joint block is placed across the expansion gap, and thus, the adequate management of accuracy of each member if given may be adapted to prevent the differences in level from occurring in any joint portion between the joint block and the traveling path. The use of a joint block made of the same concrete as that of the traveling path may be adapted to provide more substantially increased slip resistance to the tires, as compared with the rubber or steel expansion joint. A high-strength fiber-reinforced concrete joint block is as highly durable as hardly worn away, and is thus considered to be suitably applicable to the joint block for use in the present invention. The joint block is firmly fixed in three positions to the upside of the backing plate by reason that the loose holes respectively take the shapes as described the above.

3. The laminated rubber is formed by piling up a thin rubber layer and a steel sheet alternately in multiple layers to place the rubber layers under restraint so that it will be hard to be deformed vertically and vice verse easy to be deformed horizontally in a soft manner. The laminated rubber is formed in the shape of a rectangular parallelepiped lengthwise in the direction perpendicular to the axis of the traveling path. The laminated rubber is fixedly placed in detachable fashion on a bottom of each of the step by fastening the base plate to the bottom with more than one anchor bolt. The laminated rubber is supposed to get deformed as a unit, following the expansion or contraction or the like of the bridge girders.

4. The expansion gap in the joint between the traveling paths is blocked up with the joint block so that an expansion gap

<summary>

1. The present invention relates to track transport systems, specifically floor track systems used in sanitary fluid treatment chambers for transporting food stuffs on wheeled hand trucks. This invention aims to prevent the contamination of the treatment fluid by the wheels of the hand trucks.

2. In the conventional method of chilling cooked meat products, racks or hand trucks loaded with cooked meat are rolled into a cooling chamber and chilled air is circulated to cool the meat. However, this method has the major drawback of evaporating meat juices and causing excessive dehydration and shrinkage of the product.

3. More recent approaches to chilling cooked meat products employ fluid treatment chambers with a system for showering the meat products with a chilled brine solution to quickly transfer the heat from the meat to the solution. This method allows for the recovery and reuse of the brine solution.

4. The meat products processed in this manner are generally for human consumption and must be processed in a sanitary environment as required by the U.S. Department of Agriculture. The method of transporting cooked meat into and out of the fluid treatment chamber must maintain the sanitary condition of the chamber as well as the recovered brine solution.

5. One transport system used with a certain degree of success in cooling chambers is the overhead rail or trolley onto which product carriers, such as racks or trees, are suspended and automatically moved or manually pushed and pulled by a gaff or similar device. However, this system has the disadvantage of fixing the route of transfer.

6. Another transport system used is the wheeled dolly-like floor trucks, which can be pushed to any desired destination or stored at remote locations. However, the mobility advantage gained by these trucks is offset by the unsanitary nature of the wheels.

7. The present invention aims to provide a floor transport system that allows dolly-like floor trucks to be used in a fluid treatment center in a manner that prevents the wheels or other support structure on the dolly from contaminating the treatment fluid.

8. The enclosed floor track system of the present invention includes a wheel channel into which the wheels of the truck roll, and which is disposed above the fluid level on the floor by support legs. The wheel channel includes opposed sidewalls, one of which extends upwardly more than the other and which has attached to it a cover plate horizontally overlying the top of the channel.

9. The enclosed floor track system shown in FIG. 2 prevents showered or dripping brine from entering into the track system, and what little solution which may enter the tracks and become contaminated

<summary>
1. The present invention relates to a lock device for a work machine, particularly a lock device for a boom of a backhoe work machine, which prevents the boom from being rotated downward by its weight.
2. The lock device comprises an engaging member, an engaged member, and a guide member, where the engaging member is provided on one of the boom and a boom bracket, and the engaged member is provided on the other of the boom and the boom bracket.
3. The engaging member is constituted by a plate formed with a hook part and a slot, and is supported by a support pin and a guide member, which guide the engaging member to a prescribed position.
4. The lock device is adoptable for locking a boom, an arm, or the like in the state of stored in a main body, and is available in an excavating device, a loader, a crane, and the like.
</summary>

1. The present invention relates to swimming pool vacuum cleaning devices, specifically a swimming pool vacuum cleaning apparatus having a flexible platform with a central, vacuum portion that is readily adjustable relative to the pool bottom. This adjustment enables precise regulation of suction efficiency during the pool cleaning operation. The apparatus includes a suction head assembly with a generally rectangular, horizontally extending platform and a central portion with an opening and an upwardly extending cylindrical member. The cylindrical member is adapted for interconnection with a flexible suction line.

2. The suction head assembly also includes a handle assembly pivotally interconnected with the platform, used for moving the suction head across the bottom of the pool. The platform and cylindrical member are preferably integrally formed from a yieldably deformable plastic material. A first, or outboard roller assembly is connected to the platform proximate each end portion, comprising a pair of spaced apart ribs with vertically extending slots. Each axle spans the adjacent walls and is vertically movable within the slots.

3. The central portion of the platform is provided with an opening and an upwardly extending cylindrical member, which is adapted for interconnection with a flexible suction line. The handle assembly is pivotally interconnected with the platform, used for moving the suction head across the bottom of the pool. A second, or inboard roller assembly is interconnected with the platform on either side of the central opening, comprising a weight housing with spaced apart ribs and axles that rotatably carry rollers. The inboard roller assemblies also include a weight and a cover superimposed over the weight.

4. A highly novel feature of the apparatus is a specially configured frame member connected to and spanning the platform, comprising a central portion and spaced end portions that extend outwardly on either side of the longitudinally extending edges of the platform. Each end portion of the frame member includes downwardly extending, spaced apart legs with apertures that receive the ends of axles. The central portion of the frame member is provided with an aperture that receives a connector means, which comprises a part of the adjustment means of the invention. The connector means is an elongate connector with a threaded shank portion and a head portion.

5. The roller height adjustment device of the invention can be provided in kit form for use in combination with certain types of prior art suction head assemblies. The device comprises a pair of frames that span the platform, each frame including transversely spaced end portions with apertures that receive the axles of the roller construction. The device also includes connector means for connecting each frame to the platform
