1. The invention relates to a system for compensating electromagnetic interfering fields, particularly magnetic interfering fields, using two sensors and a digital processor. The system is designed to protect an object against the effects of an interfering field. The system has three pairs of compensation coils and a control unit to generate a compensation field.

2. The system uses two real triaxial magnetic field sensors to measure the amplitude of the interfering field for all three Cartesian space axes. The measuring signals of the sensors are fed to a control loop, which calculates control or actuator signals from the measuring signals of the sensors. The control loop is used to generate a compensation field.

3. The system can be used to compensate homogeneous and inhomogeneous magnetic fields. The system can also be used to simulate the measurement of electromagnetic interfering fields at the location of the object to be protected. The system can equalize potentially arising feedback effects in the case of using two magnetic field compensation systems in immediate vicinity.

4. The system has a control unit that receives the six output signals of the two real magnetic field sensors via six inputs. The control unit combines the six output signals to three output signals of a virtual sensor using a freely definable kind of averaging. The averaging takes place by means of the control system.

5. The system uses a 6×6 matrix M to describe the averaging over the output signals of the real sensors. The matrix M is used to combine the two vectors of the real sensors to a 6-vector S. The 6-vector S is then processed by the control unit according to the algorithm.

6. The system uses an operator Ω to describe the transition from the virtual signals V to modified signals {circumflex over (V)}. The operator Ω is not necessarily a matrix, allowing for the use of nonlinear algorithms. The modified signals {circumflex over (V)} are then converted into real control signals O.

7. The system uses a 6×6 matrix L to describe the transition from the modified signals {circumflex over (V)} to the control signals O. The matrix L depends on the nature of the interfering field to be compensated and the geometry of the coils generating the compensation field.

8. The system can be used with a single compensation system or with two compensation systems placed directly beside each other. In the case of two compensation systems, feedback effects may arise between the two systems. The system uses a 6×6 back coupling matrix C to computationally eliminate the parts of the signals that are crosstalks from

<summary>
1. The invention provides a method for CARS microscopy that involves furnishing at least one resonance site in a sample by means of a bioorthogonal reaction of an intrinsic chemical structure of the sample with at least one reaction partner.
2. This method allows for the creation of resonance sites in the sample, which can be used for image production and can also be used to highlight or make visible chemical structures normally not detectable by means of CARS microscopy.
</summary>

<summary>
1. The present invention provides a system for assessing segmentations from various sources, including "gold standard" segmentations and segmentations provided by clinicians in training or different software systems.
2. The system accepts as inputs, segmentations or "regions of interest" (ROIs) recorded in electronic files, for example, using the DICOM-RT standard.
3. The segmentations are converted to volume models and the volume models are compared to identify volume elements that are missing or extra between the first and second segmentation.
4. The missing and extra volume elements may be measured and optionally weighted according to their distance from the reference (i.e. "correct") volume elements to produce an output indicating the quality of the one segmentation with respect to the other.
5. The system may also be used for periodic quality assurance of autosegmentation routines or evaluation of those routines when they are updated or used with new imaging technology.
6. The system provides an apparatus for automatically assessing radiation therapy segmentations, using an electronic computer executing a stored program to receive a first and second electronic file each providing data points describing different three-dimensional surfaces circumscribing a structure in a human patient intended for radiation therapy.
7. The system allows users to select a metric method for comparing the segmentations, which may be preestablished formulas or defined by the user.
8. The system provides a quantitative evaluation of the comparison of the two segmentations, including the primary volume, secondary volume, missing volume, extra volume, and metric method/metric score.
9. The system may be used in various applications, including the training of clinicians, periodic quality assurance testing of anatomy auto-segmentation routines and systems, and assessment of anatomy auto-segmentation routines or systems prior to customer purchase or clinical application.
</summary>

<summary>
1. The present invention relates to a method and apparatus for accelerating the effective subtraction operation in a floating point unit, which is a complex operation requiring a greater time period than standard data format operations.
2. The invention accelerates the effective subtraction operation by calculating a difference between a subset of signal positions of an operand exponent argument, which is used to begin subtraction of differences between operand fractions.
3. The subset difference is used to determine the correct resulting fraction, which is available when the complete difference is determined and the current procedure is determined to be the incorrect procedure.
4. The apparatus includes a detection and logic unit, a shift and selection logic unit, and a subtraction unit, which work together to accelerate the effective subtraction operation.
5. The invention reduces the seven major steps of the effective subtraction operation to five major steps by performing certain operations on the fly.
6. The apparatus can calculate the difference between the complete operand exponent arguments and the subset of signal positions simultaneously, allowing for faster computation.
7. The invention provides a technique for accelerating the effective subtraction operation, which is a critical component of floating point operations in data processing systems.
</summary>

<summary>

1. The present invention relates to the collection of blood and medical specimens in a medical facility, such as a hospital, and aims to reduce or avoid mislabeling of specimen vials. The invention provides a method and system for tracking a specimen acquired from a patient.

2. The prior art method of collecting a specimen involves a flow diagram that includes steps such as entering an order to draw a blood specimen, printing barcode labels, and manually comparing information on the patient's ID band to like information on the printed barcode labels. However, this method results in mislabeling of specimen vials.

3. The present invention discloses a method of tracking a specimen acquired from a patient, which includes storing machine-readable codes in a computer storage, selecting a specimen container with a unique machine-readable code, and reading and dispatching the machine-readable codes to a processor. The processor stores the machine-readable codes in a relational manner and generates a signal to acquire a specimen from the patient.

4. The method further includes inputting the patient's barcode number, order barcode number, blood drawer's barcode number, and vial barcode number into the computer, and storing these barcode numbers in a relational manner in a database data structure. The processor determines if the patient's barcode number and order barcode number are related to the same patient.

5. If the patient's barcode number and order barcode number are related, the processor stores the blood drawer's barcode number and each vial barcode number in a relational manner in the database data structure. The processor also causes a signal to be output to inform the blood drawer to draw the blood sample and send it to a lab for analysis.

6. The processor starts a software or hardware timer to determine that the blood draw is completed within a predetermined time after the signal is output. When the blood draw is complete, the blood drawer causes an indication thereof to be input into the computer.

7. The processor stores the indication in a relational manner with the patient's information, the order barcode number, the patient's barcode number, the blood drawer's barcode number, and each vial barcode number. The lab receiving each vial containing a blood sample has all of the order and "label" information stored in the database data structure that is linked to the vial barcode number.

</summary>

<summary>
1. The invention is a voice-activated distance measuring device that provides distance and other information to a golfer. It uses voice recognition technology and GPS technology to provide the user with required data on the golf course and its parameters in a verbal electronically spoken form. The device may be incorporated into an article of clothing, such as a hat or visor, or other portable device. It may also use distance measuring technology such as infra red, optics, Doppler acoustics, and the like.

2. The device uses commercially available GPS data to convert GPS mapped longitude and latitude coordinates to measure distance and other factors. It may use any GPS system available to measure the longitude and latitude coordinates to compute the distance and other golf course parameters. The device incorporates voice recognition technology to accept voice commands from the user, which are sensed by a voice sensor, such as a bone conductance vibration sensor or a microphone. The device responds to voice commands such as "distance," "pin-placement," or any other such word or words.

3. The device incorporates voice synthesis technology to provide an audible output by electronically produced spoken words, to provide distance and other information to the user via a loudspeaker or headphone, following a verbal command from the user. The output acoustics can be adjusted for volume level and frequency filtered for any particular user requirement or application. The device may also provide in a verbal form other information such as the green size, pin placement, and other information on the golf course parameters. The device may be used for such applications as hiking, surveyors, and hunters, and other applications.

4. The device may be provided with a communications method, such as a serial, USB, or wireless connection to a separate personal computer or similar technology provided by the user of this device. The device may be able to upload and download data to the separate computer to facilitate various detailed functions, such as graphical display of the user's score and plot of all ball trajectories viewed against an image of the subject golf course. The connection may also facilitate uploading of new course databases to the device and management thereof, training of voice recognition commands, and management of those commands. The device may also be used for scuba divers using an underwater design which may use any latitude and longitude measurement technology.

5. The device may include Bluetooth technology for five primary purposes, data transfers, as an audio server, as an audio client, short range audio communications, and as a remote GPS. As a Bluetooth audio server, it will be possible for the user to use a

<summary>
1. The present invention relates to a design rule checking system and method that accurately reports appropriate errors for appropriate regions in a system that includes two different kinds of circuits, such as memory and logic.
2. The invention eliminates false errors caused by design rule checking tools examining regions that are not subject to the same design rules supported by the design rule-checking tool.
3. The system and method of the present invention provide a customized design rule checking system that applies the right set of rules to the right regions of the mask pattern data.
4. The invention creates customized design rules for each different type of region that may be present on the chip by modifying a standard set of Logic Rules as needed.
5. The customized design rules are used to check a design in GDS form, and the results are categorized in different categories in accordance with where they occur.
6. The invention can be applied to any mask pattern database, including one having no memory blocks, or even multiple types of memory blocks.
7. The system and method of the present invention ensure that all types of memory regions have to fulfill all memory rules of their group, and all logic regions have to fulfill logic and memory rules.
</summary>

<summary>

1. The invention described in the source document is related to the use of waveguide holograms for illuminating objects with specific requirements. This invention is a continuation-in-part of a parent application and has been made with government support. The government has certain rights in this invention. The invention provides improved, controlled illumination of objects, including holograms and spatial light modulators.

2. The invention uses thin substrate waveguides, which are characterized by the relationship between the width of an incident laser beam and the thickness of the waveguide. These waveguides are controlled by the wavelength of the incident lightwave and can provide uniform illumination. The inventors have discovered that these waveguides can be particularly used for situations requiring controlled illumination. The invention provides a method for selectively illuminating demanding objects, such as holograms and spatial light modulators.

3. The illumination system claimed in the invention comprises a light source optically coupled to a waveguide, on a surface of which is formed a hologram. The waveguide hologram (WGH) is normally flat and can be optically contacted to the objects it illuminates. The WGH illuminator occupies much less space compared to conventional lens illumination systems. The active volume for a WGH illuminator is no more than the thickness of the waveguide substrate.

4. The invention provides extremely high diffraction efficiencies, with the diffraction efficiency being the fraction of the light from the illuminating source which is diffracted into the required beam. For conventional display holograms, a diffraction efficiency of 0.6 is sometimes obtained, while for holograms made by two plane waves, a diffraction efficiency of 0.99 is attainable. The WGH illuminator can also achieve very high diffraction efficiency, approaching 0.99. However, high efficiencies over large area holograms require very careful design.

5. The invention also addresses several challenges associated with WGHs, including alignment sensitivity, illumination depletion, and two-sidedness. Alignment sensitivity can be combatted by attaching the source firmly to the edge of the waveguide or by using a spatially and spectrally broad source. Illumination depletion can be compensated for a priori or a posteriori, with a posteriori compensation being very light inefficient. Two-sidedness can be addressed by absorbing the light emerging from one side or by placing a mirror on one side to reflect all of the light into the same direction.

6. The invention has been disclosed with reference to generic description and specific embodiments, and the

<summary>

1. The invention relates to a method and apparatus for testing squirrel cage rotors for induction motors to obtain the resistance, reactance, and effective electrical skew of the rotor to permit identification of rotor defects. The test apparatus comprises a test head for accepting and causing relative angular movement between the rotor and test head, exciting means for magnetizing the rotor during such angular movement, and voltage sensing means for generating a voltage signal responsive to the magnetic flux variations generated by the rotor. The test apparatus also includes current sensing means for sensing the magnitude of the alternating current utilized to magnetize the rotor.

2. The test apparatus includes processing means for determining the resistance and reactance of the rotor responsive to the voltage signal and current signal, and skew sensing means for sensing the effective electrical skew of the rotor and for generating an effective skew signal responsive thereto. The processing means is usable for determining an effective electrical skew of the rotor responsive to the effective skew signal. The test apparatus is particularly useful for testing squirrel cage rotors for induction motors.

3. The test apparatus includes a data acquisition and processing system that controls the acquisition of the test data and processes the data to produce useful test results as well as rotor pass/fail determinations. The data acquisition and processing system includes a data processor and a control processor that work together to determine the resistance, reactance, and effective skew of the rotor. The control processor also controls the sequence of events that occur during a test.

4. The test apparatus includes a retraction and drive mechanism that retracts a rotor placed on a test head and rotates the rotor at a rate of one rotation in four seconds. The retraction and drive mechanism includes a hydraulic cylinder that retracts the rotor to the test position and a drive motor that rotates the rotor. The test apparatus also includes a clutch mechanism that securely holds the rotor in place during rotation.

</summary>

<summary>
1. The present disclosure provides a method that includes granting access to native resources of an operating system in response to validating a digital certificate associated with a managed library.
2. The method also includes denying access to native resources of the operating system to a managed application that includes a digital certificate authorizing the managed application to access a specific native resource of the operating system through the managed library.
3. The disclosure further provides a method that includes receiving a request from a managed application to access a native system resource through a managed library and authorizing the request to access the native system resource through the managed library.
4. The method also includes sending a request to access the native system resource to a runtime host and accessing the native system resource by the runtime host.
5. The disclosure provides a method for publishing videogames configured to execute on a mobile device, including receiving a package from a networked computer system, identifying an executable in the package, and verifying managed metadata associated with the executable.
</summary>

<summary>
1. The invention relates to an improved identification card containing an internal antenna and integrated circuit chip laminated between two protective, non-rigid layers onto which artwork may be printed, which are then laminated between two rigid outer layers. This design protects the electronic components from damage and is easier to manufacture than prior art identification cards. The card can be personalized with various security features, such as UV sensitive inks or Polasecure.

2. The identification card consists of a core layer, a bottom layer, and two polymer layers, with the core layer and bottom layer being made of an opaque white reflective polyolefin. The core layer and bottom layer are joined with an adhesive layer, and the electronic components are sandwiched between them. The polymer layers provide mechanical strength to the image-receiving layer or layers.

3. The invention provides a low-cost, easily constructed identification card that protects electronic components from damage and is easier to manufacture than prior art identification cards. The card can be personalized with various security features, such as UV sensitive inks or Polasecure. The invention also provides a unique structure capable of protecting the IC chip and antenna, making it a significant improvement over prior art identification cards and smart cards.
</summary>

<summary>
1. The invention relates to the implementation of a memory, specifically a FIFO-type queue, in a functional memory environment.
2. In a functional memory, updates are made by copying the path from the root of a tree-shaped structure to the point of updating and then making the update in the copied data.
3. A typical implementation of a FIFO queue is a double-ended list, but this is ineffective for functional memories as each update would result in copying the entire queue.
4. The invention provides a novel way of establishing a queue using a tree-shaped structure to reduce the amount of required copying.
5. The tree-shaped structure has nodes with a given maximum size and is balanced, with all leaf nodes at the same level and all internal nodes full except for those on the edges.
6. Additions to the queue are made by directing data units to the first non-full node on the first edge of the tree, while deletions are directed to a leaf node on the opposite edge.
7. The invention also includes a header node that makes use of an identifier indicating which edge of the queue constitutes the beginning and which the end.
8. The header node can be used to invert the queue in constant time and space, and the queue can be used as a double-ended queue.
9. The invention can be implemented in a memory arrangement with a tree structure, intermediate registers, and control logic to maintain the queue.
10. The invention can be modified within the scope of the inventive idea disclosed in the appended claims, and the maximum size of the nodes can follow a pattern or be fixed.
</summary>

<summary>
1. The present invention provides a method to manufacture embedded EPROM devices using existing IC manufacture technologies, which can be used for DRAM redundancy circuits and other applications, and does not require high voltages for its operations.
2. The invention also includes a stress effect programmable read only memory (SEPROM) device that uses the damages caused by electrical stresses on common transistors to store data, which can be manufactured by any IC technologies and is ideal for embedded applications.
</summary>

<summary>

1. The invention relates to a technique of easily and quickly determining the optimum value of feedback gain used for calculating correction amount in feedback control. This technique is particularly useful for applications such as moving an automatic guidance vehicle along a predetermined course.

2. The prior art method of determining feedback gain involves a limit sensitivity process, which has problems in detecting self-sustaining vibration and may be difficult to apply in certain situations. The invention aims to provide a method of determining feedback gain that is easy, accurate, and can be applied in a short period of time.

3. The method of determining feedback gain according to the invention involves a series of steps, including provisionally determining a predetermined value of a feedback gain, executing feedback control using the provisionally determined feedback gain, and detecting an error between a designated value and an actual value of the subject of control.

4. The invention introduces evaluation values for the individual P, I, and D gains, which are suited for accurately evaluating the influence of the value of each gain on the voltage curve. The evaluation functions are used to determine the optimum values of the P, I, and D gains.

5. The evaluation functions are used to evaluate the stability, accuracy, and response of the control system. The functions LR, Svv, and Asv are used to evaluate the P, I, and D gains, respectively.

6. The optimum values of the P, I, and D gains are determined by using the evaluation functions and a predetermined range or by function interpolation. The optimum values are calculated by plotting the evaluation function values and determining the minimum point.

7. The invention is applicable to various types of feedback control systems, including those used in automatic guidance vehicles, and can be used to determine the optimum values of feedback gains other than the P, I, and D gains. The invention provides a flexible and efficient method for determining feedback gain.

</summary>

1. The invention relates to zoom lenses with increased relative aperture and good optical performance over the entire zooming range, while minimizing the physical size and total length. The zoom lens comprises five lens units, including a first unit of positive power for focusing, a second unit of negative power for varying the image magnification, a third unit of negative power for compensating for the shift of an image plane, a fourth unit of positive power for making the diverging light beam almost parallel, and a fifth unit of positive, negative, positive, negative, positive, and positive powers for image forming. The conditions for the construction and arrangement of the elements of the fourth and fifth lens units are crucial for achieving good correction of aberrations. The inequalities of conditions (1)-(4) give a range of refractive power ratio for the second lens in the fifth lens unit, the refractive power ratio for the fourth and fifth lenses, and the Abbe numbers of the media of the first and sixth lenses.

2. The inequalities of condition (1) represent the range of refracting power for the rear surface of the first lens in the fourth lens unit, while condition (2) gives a range of refractive power ratio for the second lens in the fifth lens unit to well correct spherical aberration. Condition (3) gives a range of refractive power ratio for the fourth and fifth lenses in the fifth lens unit to well correct astigmatism without causing other aberrations. Condition (4) gives a range of the Abbe numbers of the media of the first and sixth lenses in the fifth lens unit to correct longitudinal and lateral chromatic aberrations in good balance. The conditions are essential for achieving high grade optical performance throughout the entire zooming range.

3. The fourth lens unit is a bi-convex lens with the rear surface of strong curvature toward the rear, while the fifth lens unit comprises a bi-convex first lens, a negative meniscus-shaped second lens, a positive third lens, a negative meniscus-shaped fourth lens, a bi-convex fifth lens, and a positive sixth lens. The air separation between the third and fourth lenses is longest in this lens unit. By designing the fourth and fifth lens units in such a way, the residual aberrations of the zoom section are corrected entirely in good balance. The technical significances of the above-defined conditions are explained below.

1. The invention relates to a method and device for detecting elementary particles such as protons, ions, electrons, neutrons, photons, or the like, which enables both the detection of individual particles and the integration of count rates.
2. The method involves discharging a charge pulse or signal from the detector on the low-voltage side, allowing for the detection of small-size signals and preventing leakage current in high-voltage cables.
3. The device includes a detector, a first, fast amplifier, and a second, slow amplifier, which are connected in a way that allows for the detection of individual particles and the integration of count rates.
4. The first amplifier is used for amplifying individual signals, while the second amplifier is used for integrating signals upon exceeding a threshold value of the rate of the signals.
5. The signals are separated as a function of the rate by a capacitor preceding the first amplifier or an inductive element preceding the second amplifier.
6. The invention also proposes the use of a material enabling fast charge transport at room temperature, such as diamond, as the detector material.
7. The device can be used for detecting particles in various applications, including particle accelerators, reactor installations, diagnostic devices, and medical technology.
8. The invention enables the detection of elementary particles without knowing in advance signal rates to be expected, making it suitable for various applications where high accuracy and reliability are required.
</summary>

<summary>

1. The invention relates to an improved apparatus for automatically spin checking a driven disc assembly, which is used in friction clutches to selectively connect a source of rotational power to a driven mechanism. The apparatus is designed to determine whether the driven disc assembly is within specified tolerances and generate external indications to the operator of the condition of the tested assembly.

2. The prior test fixture for measuring the warpage of a driven disc assembly included a splined hub, a stationary ring, and a movable ring, which were actuated by a pneumatic cylinder to move the movable ring toward the stationary ring. However, this fixture was slow and inefficient in the production environment and required several manual operations to be performed by an operator.

3. The improved apparatus includes an enclosure with a stationary ring mounted thereon and a movable ring slidably supported thereon, which are connected to a torque motor and a servo motor. The torque motor exerts a predetermined amount of torque on the driven disc assembly, while the servo motor controls the movement of the movable ring.

4. The apparatus also includes an electronic position sensor, which generates an electrical signal representative of the distance from the sensor to the target, and an optical encoder, which generates an electrical signal representative of the direction and magnitude of rotation of the output shaft of the torque motor. These signals are used to determine the warpage of the driven disc assembly.

5. The microprocessor controls the operation of the torque motor and the servo motor, as well as generates signals to a display to provide the operator with a visual indication of the status of the apparatus. The microprocessor also stores specific measurements for each assembly being tested for statistical process control.

6. The program executed by the microprocessor includes instructions to read the signals generated by the control switches, determine if a start signal has been generated, and actuate the servo motor to rotate the ball screw shaft at a relatively fast speed in a first rotational direction. The program also includes instructions to read the value of the signal from the sensor portion of the servo motor and determine if the right ring has frictionally engaged the driven disc assembly.

7. When the right ring has frictionally engaged the driven disc assembly, the program discontinues the actuation of the servo motor and reads the value of the signal generated by the position sensor. The program also reads the initial value of the signal generated by the optical encoder and actuates the torque motor to exert a predetermined amount of torque on the driven disc assembly.

8. The program then actuates the servo motor to rotate the ball

1. The present invention relates to the field of image processing, specifically face age-estimation and methods, systems, and software therefor. Face recognition is one of the most difficult and challenging tasks in computer vision, partly because of large variations in human faces. The difficulty and challenge are even higher for face age-estimation. Researchers have been developing technologies for face age-estimation due to the demands of many real-world operating scenarios that require accurate, efficient, uncooperative, and cost-effective solutions.

2. Accurate age-estimation may be of great benefit to businesses, such as convenience stores, restaurants, and others, who are required to forbid underage access to, for example, alcohol or tobacco. Age-estimation systems can also be applicable in homeland security technologies, criminal identification, management of e-documents and electronic customer relationships, all without requiring imposing password prompts, password change reminders, etc. In restaurants and other businesses, age-recognition systems may be used to help identify trends in business relative to the ages of customers. Additionally, these systems can help to prevent children from viewing or otherwise consuming unacceptable media or programming.

3. The aging of human faces is a complicated process influenced by many factors such as gender, ethnicity, heredity factors, and environmental factors, including cosmetic interventions, societal pressure, relative sun exposure, and drug or alcohol consumption. In this process, there are some controllable factors (i.e., gender, ethnicity, heredity, etc.) that can be exploited in order to recognize trends in the aging of human faces. However, other uncontrollable factors, such as environment, living styles, and sun exposure (photoaging), can prove quite challenging to deal with. Therefore, correctly estimating an age from a face is a huge challenge even for humans, let alone for computing devices.

4. The effects of age on the human face have been studied in numerous research fields, including orthodontics, anthropology, anatomy, forensic art, and cognitive psychology. However, compared to these aging-related fields, computer science approaches for aging problems are relatively new. From the viewpoint of computer science, face aging technologies generally address two areas: face age-estimation and face age-progression. The face age-estimation problem can be addressed with computer software that has the ability to recognize the ages of individuals in a given photo.

5. To achieve an accurate, efficient, uncooperative, and cost-effective solution to the problem of face age-estimation, it becomes necessary to extract as

1. The present invention relates to a matrix display device for displaying two merged images, particularly suited for simultaneous display of two images with different definitions. The device comprises a controller and a matrix of pixels organized in a mosaic of identical arrangements of pixels. Each arrangement can be formed by a square of four pixels, with three pixels dedicated to the display of a first image and the remaining pixel dedicated to the display of a second image. The controller produces display light intensity signals for each pixel and applies them to the pixels to form the merged image.

2. The matrix display device can be configured to display a first image, essentially monochrome, produced by a night vision sensor or by an infrared sensor or by an X-ray imaging sensor, merged with the display of a second image, essentially monochrome, produced by an infrared sensor, by an echography sensor, or a monochrome or two-color symbology image. The device can also display a plurality of combined images, with arrangements of pixels in which pixels are dedicated to different images out of the plurality of images. The controller can be configured to apply an attenuation function to the light intensity signals to be applied to the pixels, to correct the display of the first image and to obtain a good saturation of the colors of the second image. The attenuation function can be applied according to a predetermined relationship, for example, Si=b ·exp(− a·S 1 i )· S 1 i.

3. The matrix display device can be based on a dedicated hardware architecture, offering an advantage in terms of lower consumption in operation. An exemplary hardware architecture may be based on a matrix of pixels associated with two controllers. The first controller can be interfaced with three pixels of each arrangement, and the second controller can be interfaced with the remaining pixel of each arrangement. The video stream intended for a display on the matrix display device can be displaced in interleaved manner, in the form of a first video stream generated by the first controller and of a second video stream generated by the second controller.

4. The matrix display device can be used to display a first image originating from a night vision sensor with a second image derived from an infrared sensor targeting the same scene. The first image can be a monochrome image, with a definition of 2000×2000 pixels, and the second image can be monochrome, with a lower resolution, for example 480×480 pixels. The matrix display device can comprise a video controller, a first video interface with the night vision sensor, a second video interface

<summary>
1. The invention relates to a mobile identification transmitter for activating a security system of a motor vehicle, particularly an access and/or ignition control system, which has a housing with electronics and a communication means. The communication means can be brought into communication with a communication means of the security system located on board the motor vehicle.

2. The mobile identification transmitter has a payment element that can be removed from the housing, allowing the user to carry out various payment actions, such as at a gas station or shopping center. The payment element can remain inside the housing during the payment process.

3. The payment element can be brought into data communication with an electronic payment system, and it can have a credit card function and/or a debit card function. The payment element can also have a microprocessor and a storage device to carry out complex calculation algorithms and store codes.

4. The mobile identification transmitter has a secure state in which the payment element is removed from the receptacle, and a closure protects the contact elements from the external environment. In this state, communication is possible between the identification transmitter and the security system, but payment actions are blocked.

5. The closure can be designed as a dummy plug, a cap that pivots about an axis, or a component that moves translationally between its active and passive positions. The closure can also serve as an advertisement or information board on which information can be applied.
</summary>

<summary>

1. An imaging device, such as a xerographic machine, becomes inactive when not in use, and when it becomes inactive for a long period of time, the device is often put into a “sleep mode” to save energy. When the imaging device “wakes up” from the sleep mode, the device starts warming up and performs imaging operations with toner.

2. The toner used in such an imaging device is charged with a tribo-electro-static charge, and a toner concentration (TC) sensor measures the concentration of the toner in the developer by detecting the tribo charge of the toner. The TC sensor adjusts the supply of toner to increase the concentration of the toner when the concentration of toner is low.

3. If the imaging device is inactive for a long period of time, the tribo charge of the toner may decrease, which greatly affects the image quality in an imaging operation. Therefore, the image quality in an imaging operation after a delayed period may become inconsistent and darker than the image quality during normal or continual use.

4. The exemplary embodiments address these and other issues by determining one or more periods of inactivity of the imaging device and charging the toner to a predetermined level based on the determined period of inactivity. The method for charging toner used in an imaging device may also include measuring a toner charge level when the printing machine is recovered from the inactivity.

5. An apparatus for charging a developer in an imaging device may include an inactivity determining section that determines one or more periods of inactivity of the imaging device, and a charging section that charges the toner to a predetermined level. The apparatus may also include a user usage pattern determining section that determines a usage pattern of the user.

6. The inactivity determining section may include a predicting section that predicts the next user usage from the determination made by the inactivity determining section. The predicting section may predict when the user is expected to next use the machine based on a user usage pattern.

7. The inactivity determining section may also include a measuring section that measures the TC sensor, and a calculating section that calculates a decay of the tribo charge of the toner based on the difference between any two sensor levels of the TC sensor. The calculating section may calculate the decay using the sensor level at the beginning of the inactivity period and the sensor level at the end of the inactivity period.

8. The inactivity determining section may further include an updating section that updates information on the user

<summary>

1. The present invention relates to a rotary magnetic head type apparatus that permits independent and precise regulation of bias currents supplied to plural MR heads mounted on a rotary drum in a simple structure. The apparatus includes a control signal generator for generating control signals for controlling the operating amperages of magneto resistive heads and a decoder circuit for discriminating data of the control signals. The control signals are transmitted over a single channel of a rotary transformer and set the operating currents of the magneto resistive heads. This structure enables the bias currents for the MR heads to be controlled with a one-channel control signal sent from the stationary drum side.

2. The invention further provides a recording/reproducing apparatus permitting switching over among plural heads with high precision, in particular a rotary magnetic head type apparatus permitting switching over plural MR heads and recording heads mounted on a rotary drum at high speed. The apparatus includes a recording/reproducing unit for recording/reproducing signals onto/from a recording medium with plural heads, a generating unit for generating control data for controlling the recording/reproducing unit, and a transmitting unit for transmitting control data generated by the generating unit to the recording/reproducing unit. Data for controlling the switching over among the plurality of heads are transmitted with priority over other control data. This structure enables the switching over among the plural heads to be performed with high precision.

3. The invention can be applied to various types of apparatuses, including disk apparatuses, and can be used for the transmission of frequency-modulated analog signals. The invention is particularly useful for apparatuses provided with MR heads, where not only head switching data but also data for controlling bias currents have to be transmitted at the time of head switching. The invention can also be applied to other types of apparatuses in which plural heads are controlled by a recording/regenerative integrated circuit or circuits. The invention can help prevent erroneous operation due to a delay in data transmission at the time of switching over between plural heads.

</summary>

<summary>
1. The invention is concerned with locating and tracing concealed elongated conductive objects, such as pipes or cables, and improving the ease and accuracy of this process when a second object is adjacent to the first.
2. The prior art uses two general techniques: a passive technique employing a gradiometer and an active technique using a transmitter to induce alternating currents in non-ferrous metal pipes.
3. The invention employs a transmitter with a pair of antennae that generate corresponding magnetic fields, inducing distinguishable currents in the cables, and a receiver that senses both fields and produces an output signal dependent upon their presence.
4. The system of the invention is capable of producing two distinct output signal nulls over respective cables, allowing for easier and more accurate location and tracing of one or both cables.
5. The invention uses various techniques to distinguish the currents in the respective cables, including different carrier frequencies, amplitude modulation, and pulsing at different repetition rates.
6. The invention is especially useful in environments where the horizontal separation between cables is related to the depth of the cable to be located and traced, and the effect achieved by the invention is enhanced by the phenomenon of the field from the transmitter decreasing by the inverse cube of the distance between an antennae and a cable.
</summary>

1. The invention relates to an apparatus for interfacing a speaker phone with a telephone network to permit hands-free automatic answering and communication. This invention is particularly advantageous for the physically handicapped or for an outpatient during a period of convalescence to respond to an inquiry from trained hospital personnel. Hands-free conversation is also advantageous for persons whose activities make handling a telephone difficult or dangerous. Such individuals include those having wet or soiled hands, such as an employee of a laundry, cooks, hairdressers, automobile mechanics, or those people whose tasks require the use of both hands as a part of the work task.

2. The apparatus includes a source of power for the interfacing apparatus, such as by the use of a transformer connected to a wall outlet in a home. Selective switch means are provided for selectively connecting, when actuated, the interfacing apparatus with the telephone network to permit telephone operation in either a conventional manner or in an automatic answering mode. When in the automatic answering mode, a coupler is provided for automatically coupling the telephone network to the speaker device to receive incoming telephone calls on the speaker device when the selector switch is actuated. The apparatus also includes a timer for controlling the length of time of such interconnection and a bypass switch for bypassing the timer.

3. The invention includes two embodiments of the interfacer. The first embodiment includes an optically coupled circuit for coupling the telephone ringing circuit in a manner which discharges a charging capacitor to a predetermined signal level. Means are responsive to the discharge of the capacitor to a predetermined signal level to connect the speaker phone to the telephone lines automatically in a hands-free manner in response to the telephone ringing signal. A timer is connected in circuit with the output of the optocoupler for limiting the time duration during which the telephone network is coupled to the speaker phone. A reset switch is provided in cooperation with the timer for canceling the predetermined time cycle in the timer upon command.

4. The second embodiment of the interfacer includes a neon lamp optically coupled with a photocell having a resistance inversely proportional to the amount of light incident on the cell. As the light increases and the resistance of the photocell decreases, the current through a photocell relay increases to latch contacts to couple the speaker phone to the telephone line. A timing and extension feature as in the previous embodiment are also provided. The invention may be embodied in other specific forms without departing from its spirit or essential characteristics.

5. The invention provides a simplified, portable, readily connectable, automatic

<summary>

1. The present invention relates to the field of optical fiber communications, specifically to system network design and incorporation of branch powered amplification within such networks. The invention aims to reduce or eliminate undersea optical repeaters in a trunk and branch ring network. This is achieved by replacing repeaters with remotely pumped optical amplifiers and remotely supplying energy to those optical amplifiers over the same branch cables that also distribute communications signals.

2. The invention utilizes a trunk and branch structure with a ring geometry, which exhibits strong survivability features. An arbitrary single trunk cut leaves all nodes connected, and any number of simultaneous branch cuts simply isolate the corresponding branches. This allows all other communications to remain enabled within the trunk ring and further allows access to the trunk by the remaining unsevered branches.

3. The invention also utilizes a light emitting power source to supply energy to the optical amplifier. The light emitting power source is coupled onto the branch fiber optic cable or the optical fiber cable trunk, and the energy is transferred unidirectionally over the cable. The energy is then used to amplify attenuated optical fiber cable trunk communication signals.

4. The invention uses a multiple order cascaded Raman laser as the light emitting power source, producing an output light source with a wavelength in the range of 1450-1500 nm. The wavelength of the light source must be distinct from the band of signal wavelengths contemplated for transmission along the optical fiber cable trunk or the branch fiber optic cable. This ensures that the energy source does not interfere with the signal wavelengths.

5. The invention also uses an erbium doped fiber amplifier as the optical amplifier, which is capable of amplifying signals in the 1500-1600 nm range. The optical amplifier is spliced or coupled with the optical fiber cable trunk or the branch fiber optic cable, and its exact location is determined by the network designer. The maximum distance between the light emitting power source and the optical amplifier is currently limited to about one hundred kilometers.

6. The invention provides a number of advantages, including a single optical fiber cable trunk cut maintaining full connectivity along the trunk and to all cable stations. Branch fiber optic cable cuts simply isolate the associated cable station without compromising ring integrity. The invention also respects sovereignty concerns and allows for reconfigurable wavelength add/drop branching units.

7. The invention can be applied to other methods of signal multiplexing and may also be used as a terrestrial communications system instead of in an undersea application. The invention is particularly well suited as an undersea application of

2. The device consists of a two-part system, including an attachment plate that is attached to the wiring device using available fasteners, and a cover plate that is attached to the attachment plate without visible fasteners, allowing for easy installation and removal.

<summary>
1. The present invention relates to a collapsible light-shielding device for a screen, which consists of annular strips that are concentrically nested and essentially enclose one another in a tight manner, allowing for various angular positions relative to the screen.
2. The light-shielding device is designed to be foldable, taking up relatively little space when folded in, and can be easily fitted to a screen using Velcro or other attachment methods.

<summary>
1. The invention relates to automated speech technologies that provide an indication to a speaker when their rate of speech is likely to be greater than a rate that a listener can comprehend.
2. The device can monitor the rate of speech during a discourse and provide an indicator warning the speaker to slow down when the rate is too rapid for listener comprehension.
3. The device can include a microphone, a sensory mechanism, a speaking rate processor, a language detector, a speech clarity processor, and a comprehension comparator to determine the speaking rate and language proficiency of the listener.
4. The device can also include a network element that performs speech processing operations, such as determining the speaking rate and language proficiency of the listener, and provides the results to the device.
5. The device can automatically notify the speaker to decrease their speaking rate when the speaking rate exceeds the listening rate threshold, and can also suggest an alternative language that the speaker and listener share.
</summary>

<summary>
1. The invention aims to provide a device for the optical recording of rapid processes with a TV camera, allowing for a higher picture sequence frequency with simple means and flexibility.
2. The device comprises a cyclic line counter, a sawtooth generator, and a beam suppression circuit, which work together to control the scanning beam and suppress the beam during line and picture change periods.
3. The cyclic line counter counts the output pulses from the pulse former and supplies a pulse after a predetermined number of counting steps, which is used to control the sawtooth generator and beam suppression circuit.
4. The device can be adjusted to achieve the optimal time resolution and spatial resolution for the process being recorded, and can also be used for recording IR, UV, or X-ray pictures.
</summary>

<summary>

1. The present invention relates to multimedia communications and provides a technique for handling multimedia calls with clients having legacy phones and services. This technique allows existing customer premises equipment and network elements to be used to support multimedia capabilities.

2. The invention takes an incoming call from a remote caller and accesses a database to determine if the intended recipient of the phone call has blended capabilities. If the answer is negative, the call is handled according to conventional protocols.

3. If the intended recipient supports blended calling, the telephony server directs the call to a multimedia server, and the blender software receives the call request and initiates a single session with two call components: a voice call component and a multimedia call component.

4. The voice call component is handled through the telephony server, and the multimedia call component is handled through the multimedia server. The blender software may integrate the signaling paths into a single signal path as part of the single session.

5. The present invention is well suited for use with a Session Initiation Protocol for Telephones (SIP-T) configuration, and an Intelligent Network (IN) signal may be used to determine if a blended call is being handled.

6. The communication environment includes a communication network, two clients connected to the network, and a telephony server and a multimedia server positioned throughout the network. The telephony server and the multimedia server interact with each other and other components in the communication network via a Session Initiation Protocol for Telephones (SIP-T).

7. The invention takes incoming and outgoing calls associated with a client and routes the call to the blender associated with the telephony server. The blender then initiates two parallel components for the call: a voice component and a multimedia component.

</summary>

<summary>
1. The present invention is related to concurrently filed, commonly assigned, application Ser. No. ______ [Attorney Docket No. 10018268-1], entitled Smart Phonebook Search; and application Ser. No. ______ [Attorney Docket No. 10018267-1], entitled Smart Content Information Merge and Presentation. The present invention generally relates to electronic service delivery and specifically to content synchronization frameworks using dynamic attributes and file bundles for connected devices. Existing methods for data synchronization between a device and a server are generally carried out based on a predefined set of attributes. Typically, data synchronization on the basis of an arbitrary set of attributes, either internal or external to the synchronization framework, is not supported.

2. The present invention provides a content synchronization framework that allows any connected device or appliance to perform contextual synchronization over a wide variety of communication network topologies. The present systems and methods make use of transport optimization such as data compression to save bandwidth and time over low bandwidth connections. The present synchronization framework provides a central reference point, such as a server or group of servers, and each communicating device synchronizes to the content determined by this central reference point. The present invention is highly scalable, preferably due to the client device performing a major portion of processing.

3. The present systems and methods preferably have flexibility to support content synchronization, at any point in time, based on device context. This context may be in the form of arbitrary dynamic attributes sent to a central reference point by the client. The present systems and methods preferably employ file compression and concurrent priority based downloading to further optimize the present synchronization algorithm and to optimize communication bandwidth usage. The client device preferably composes a delta list of all the files in the bundle that are different from local copies available to the client device.

4. The present content synchronization frameworks preferably provide for creation of the aforementioned delta list embodying differences between a client's local copy of a file or data and the central reference point indicated file or data. Creation of this delta list is preferably performed by the client device and thus the present systems and methods are highly scalable as the work is distributed instead of being carried out by one server. The client preferably retrieves the files in the ordered delta list from various servers indicated in the bundles. The files downloaded are also preferably compressed to save download time over slow and/or low bandwidth connections.

</summary>

<summary>

1. The present invention is a system and method for allowing a person to anonymously communicate with the owner of a lost or misplaced object. The system includes a unique ID and a reference to a specific website or virtual locale on a tag attached to the object. The tag can be a printed adhesive label, a sew-on patch, a plastic key-ring tag, or an electronic tag.

2. The owner can register the tag ID and contact information on a centralized and network-accessible database. The database is queried for any open cases where the user's userid is listed as the owner. The retrieved records are used to create a list of open cases, which is displayed to the user.

3. The user can view open cases, close cases, and communicate with the finder of a particular case. The user can also edit their account settings, including their name, addresses, password, and contact information. The user can select to return to the main owner menu without entering any information.

4. A finder can access the system by selecting the finder option on the website. The finder can register as a new user, log in, and view open cases. The finder can also edit their account settings, including their name, addresses, password, and contact information.

5. The system allows a finder to send a quick one-way anonymous message to the owner or open a new case and communicate using anonymous email addresses. The finder can enter an email message into a provided field and select to send the message. The message is directed to the real email address of the owner associated with the entered ID.

6. The system checks for incoming email and forwards it to the owner's real email address. The system also checks for incoming messages from multiple messaging protocols and forwards them to the owner's designated IM addresses. The system creates a new message that may optionally include an introduction and sends it to the owner's email address and IM addresses.

</summary>

<summary>

1. The invention was made with government support under Contract No. W-7405-ENG-36 awarded by the U.S. Department of Energy, and the government has certain rights in the invention. The present invention relates generally to electron multipliers and, more particularly, to electron multipliers used in photomultipliers and particle detectors.

2. Two types of conventional electron multipliers are routinely used: discrete dynode multipliers and continuous electron multipliers. Discrete dynode multipliers consist of dynode stages that initiate and amplify a cascade of electrons.

3. Continuous electron multipliers, such as channel electron multipliers and microchannel plates, employ one or more high resistivity glass channels or tubes that act as a series of continuous dynodes. These multipliers are used extensively in electron spectrometers, mass spectrometers, and photonic detectors.

4. The present invention includes a foil electron multiplier, which encompasses the next generation design of electron multipliers. The foil electron multiplier uses a sequential series of thin foils in an evacuated enclosure that act to multiply electrons in a series of transmission stages.

5. The foil electron multiplier comprises a series of thin foils held by foil holders in an evacuated enclosure that form discrete multiplication stages. The foils are arranged collinearly, although they can be arranged in an array along an arc.

6. The gain of a foil electron multiplier is maximized by maximizing the electron transmission through the foil, transmission through the support grid, and secondary electron emission yield. The gain is represented by Equation 2, which takes into account the probability of incident particle transmission, transmission through the foil, and secondary electron emission yield.

7. The foil electron multiplier exhibits an intrinsic rejection of ion feedback at each stage, which is a limitation of continuous electron multipliers. Ions generated at one foil may be accelerated back to the previous foil, but cannot be re-transmitted back because the ion energy is too low.

8. The foil dimensions practiced for the present invention range from about 0.5 cm diameter to 2×4 cm 2, although this range may be expanded or reduced depending on the application sought. A preferred embodiment uses a round 1 cm diameter foil.

9. The foil areal thickness can range from about 0.2 μg/cm 2 to about 2 μg/cm 2, with a preferred embodiment using a range of 0.2 to 1 μg/cm 2. Carbon is the preferred foil material due to its thinness

1. The 3-D Phenomenoscope invention relates to the field of motion pictures and provides a system to view 3-dimensional and other special effects in motion pictures. The invention uses the well-known Pulfrich effect, through which lateral motion of an ordinary motion picture will appear to the viewer in 3-Dimensions.

2. The 3-D Phenomenoscope achieves this by taking advantage of the Pulfrich effect, through which lateral motion of an ordinary motion picture will appear to the viewer in 3-Dimensions. The invention uses a computer algorithm running on a computer processor contained within the 3-D Phenomenoscope to calculate in real-time, and from a multiplicity of media frames, the synchronization and control events.

3. The preferred embodiment of the 3-D Phenomenoscope uses a computer algorithm running on a computer processor contained within the 3-D Phenomenoscope to calculate in real-time, and from a multiplicity of media frames, the synchronization and control events. The algorithm identifies passages of lateral movement in the motion picture that will display as a 3-dimensional effect when viewed using the 3-D Phenomenoscope.

4. The 3-D Phenomenoscope uses a digital photo sensor to capture the viewed motion picture as successive images and convert the captured frames to digital images for processing. The digital photo sensor is used to capture the viewed motion picture as successive images and convert the captured frames to digital images for processing.

5. The 3-D Phenomenoscope uses a computer processor and computer program to process the successive images and identify the synchronization events. The computer processor and computer program process the successive images and identify the synchronization events.

6. The 3-D Phenomenoscope uses a means to provide individual control for the darkening of the right and left hand lenses based on the identified synchronization events. The means to provide individual control for the darkening of the right and left hand lenses is used to control the state of the lenses of the 3-D Phenomenoscope.

7. The 3-D Phenomenoscope uses a digital sensor to take pictures or snapshots of the displayed motion picture, a processor to process the recorded images in successive frames and identify synchronization events, and can send signals to independently control the darkness of the right and left lenses based on the detected synchronization events. The digital sensor, processor, and signals are used to control the state of the lenses of the 3-D Phenomenoscope.

8. The 3-D Phenomenoscope uses a lens control algorithm to detect similar foreground

<summary>
1. The present invention relates to an apparatus and method for the dicing of semiconductor wafers using pressure to mechanically separate the individual die from the wafer. The method includes forming trenches along the scribe lines on a semiconductor wafer and then applying a mechanical pressure to the semiconductor wafer. This pressure causes a "clean break" of the wafer along the scribe lines, thereby singulating individual die on the wafer.

2. The apparatus comprises a pad for supporting a semiconductor wafer and a positioning member to position the semiconductor wafer on the pad. A pressure mechanism is provided to apply a mechanical pressure to the wafer so as to singulate the individual die on the wafer. The pressure mechanism may include a roller, a blade, or a "squeegee" to apply the pressure.

3. The trenches are formed by applying a photo resist layer across the top surface of the wafer, patterning it to form openings over the scribe lines, and then etching the wafer to form trenches along the scribe lines. The depth of the trenches may vary from approximately ten percent to fifty percent of the thickness of the wafer. The wafer is then placed active-surface down onto a soft pad and mechanical pressure is applied to the back surface of the wafer to cause a "clean break" along the trenches, thus singulating the dice from the wafer.
</summary>

<summary>

1. The present invention relates to a field emission display device having at least one reduction plate or electrode which deflects ionic emission gas away from the field emission components of the device to prevent damage to the field emission components. This invention aims to provide a novel protection structure for preventing burn-out damage to field emission elements in a field emission display device. The protection structure includes one or multiple reduction plates or electrodes which are typically provided on the cathode.

2. The field emission display device includes a cathode provided in electrical communication with multiple field emission elements, an anode disposed in spaced-apart relationship to the cathode and the field emission elements, and an operating voltage source electrically connected to the cathode and the anode. The cathode and the anode may be any electrically-conducting metal. An operating voltage potential is applied between the cathode and the anode to establish an electric field.

3. In accordance with the present invention, a protection structure includes at least one reduction plate or electrode which is provided in the field emission device, typically on the cathode. The reduction plate is preferably any electrically-conductive metal. An insulation layer, which is an electrically-insulating material, typically separates the reduction plate from the cathode.

4. The reduction plates or electrodes are provided on the cathode plate and extend parallel and adjacent to the cathode strips on which the field emission elements are provided. A bias voltage source is electrically connected to each reduction plate for applying a negative bias voltage to the reduction plate. The negative bias voltage applied by the bias voltage source imparts a negative charge to the reduction plates.

5. The reduction plates may be fabricated on the cathode plate at the same time as the cathode strips. In manufacture, a metal material, i.e., the metal cathode plate, is first deposited on a substrate using conventional deposition techniques. Photolithography techniques are then used to form a first mask which defines the location and geometry of the cathode strips and the reduction plates on the cathode plate.

6. The reduction plates can also be formed in a meshwork-shape or a net-shape according to another exemplary embodiment of the present invention. The meshwork-shaped or net-shaped protection structure including reduction plates is provided on the cathode plate of the FED device. A bias voltage source is electrically connected to the reduction plates of the protection structure for applying a negative voltage to the reduction plates.

</summary>

<summary>
1. The present invention relates to an image sensor that includes multiple imaging planes, allowing for the simultaneous imaging of two opposing surfaces or the surface imaging of passageways.
2. Typical charge-coupled device (CCD) image sensors are formed on flat, circular semiconductor substrates known as wafers, but the present invention overcomes the limitations of these sensors.
3. The image sensor of the present invention includes a semiconductor substrate with opposed major surfaces and opposed edges, one of which has a surface receptive to light.
4. The image sensor element includes a charge collection and transfer means and an image sensing region where charge carriers are generated by light impinging on the surface of the one edge.
5. The substrate comprises a bottom layer which is highly doped with a P-type material and an upper layer which is more lightly doped with a P-type material.
6. The image sensor includes an elongated substrate of a P-type material with imaging planes on the top surface and two edge surfaces bordering the top surface.
7. The image sensor elements are formed in the substrate and include an image sensing region and a charge collecting and transfer means, such as a buried-channel CCD.
8. The P + layers in the substrate guide charge carriers toward the CCD's, allowing for the collection of charge carriers generated by light impinging on the edge surfaces.
9. The image sensor can be used in various applications, including simultaneous imaging of multiple planes, color applications, and surface imaging of passageways.
</summary>

<summary>
1. The invention relates to networks, particularly home networks, and aims to minimize power consumption while ensuring optimal administration and performance.
2. The current home network systems have a network master node that performs network administrative functions even when not performing its nominal device functions, resulting in high energy consumption.
3. The invention proposes a method for transferring network administrative functions from a master device to a slave device, allowing the master device to enter a power management state.
4. The master device sends data enabling the network administrative functions to be performed to a slave device, which then becomes the new network master node.
5. The selection of the slave device to become the new master node is based on predetermined criteria, such as visibility on the network or intelligence/functional capabilities.
6. The network slave node can accept the transfer request and become the new master node, or it can self-promote itself to the network master node role if the current master node is unplugged.
7. The invention ensures that the home network is not lost when the network master node enters into power save mode, and it optimizes the administration and performance of the network.
</summary>

<summary>
1. The invention relates to an antenna array for measuring the direction of propagation of electromagnetic radiation. The array consists of at least four antennae spaced to provide at least two equi-spaced linear triplets perpendicular to a ground plane. Each triplet is characterized by the spacing of its elements and the height of the centre element above the ground plane. The array can operate in receiving or transmitting mode.

2. The antenna array uses radio interferometric techniques to determine the elevation angle of a radio wave arriving from a remote source. The array includes radio receiver means to obtain information signals from each antenna, first logic means to combine the information signals, and second logic means to derive a second derived signal. The array also includes dividing means to divide one derived signal by the other to provide a quotient signal. The quotient signal is a function of the elevation angle but not of the ground reflection coefficient.

3. The invention provides unambiguous angle measurements up to about 7 degrees and measurement accuracy and resolution of the order +/-0.05 degrees from 3 degrees to the lowest angle possible. The array can be used in various applications, including monitoring the height of aircraft approaching to land. The invention also provides a possible arrangement for measuring the quotient {(A+C)/B}, all squared, using a divider and a timer. The system can be used to determine the range, identity, and elevation angle of an aircraft carrying a suitable transponder.
</summary>

<summary>
1. The conventional subminiature lamps have several problems, including the breakdown of adhesive due to thermal cycling, destructive shear between the glass envelope and metal sleeve, degradation of adhesive material, and corrosion of electrical contacts due to moisture migration. These problems lead to early failures of conventional subminiature lamps. The combination of these factors results in an unacceptably high failure rate.

2. The seal supported subminiature lamp assembly of the present invention utilizes a high temperature polymer that directly surrounds and is in compression contact with the glass envelope, providing a liquid tight seal and eliminating the need for adhesive or cement. The polymeric seal support makes a static radial seal with the straight sidewall of the subminiature lamp glass envelope surface, and the actual seal length is much longer than conventional "o" ring type seals. This design provides several advantages, including the elimination of adhesive or cement, closer tolerance centering of the subminiature lamp glass envelope to the axis of the abbreviated height one piece conductive base, and reduced degradation of the material of the seal between the axially bottom face and upper radial surface.
</summary>

<summary>
1. The invention relates to multiple-input multiple-output (MIMO) communications systems, specifically to precoder configuration in MIMO systems. The present invention aims to optimize system capacity or bit error rate in MU-MIMO systems.

2. The Generalized Decision Feedback Equalizer (GDFE) based precoder provides the optimal capacity solution for MU-MIMO wireless systems, but its computational cost is often prohibitive. The invention seeks to reduce the computational cost while maintaining optimal capacity.

3. The invention proposes a technique to realize a GDFE Precoder for multi-user (MU) MIMO systems, which significantly reduces the computational cost while resulting in no capacity loss. The technique is suitable for improving the performance of various MU-MIMO wireless systems.

4. The described implementation of a GDFE Precoder relaxes the requirement for knowledge of the covariance matrix (S zz ) corresponding to “Least Favorable Noise.” This is the key component in conventional design of a GDFE Precoder and requires extensive computational cost.

5. The invention provides a uniform framework for realizing a GDFE Precoder, unlike conventional GDFE Precoder design, which does not require channel reduction when the Input Covariance Matrix (S xx ) for downlink channel is rank deficient.

6. The invention achieves significant improvement in computational cost over conventional GDFE Precoders and provides a method for configuring a generalized decision feedback equalizer (GDFE) based precoder in a base station of a multi-user multiple-input multiple-output (MU-MIMO) wireless system.

</summary>

1. The invention relates to a heat-dissipating device and a housing thereof, with the main objective of enhancing the heat-dissipating performance of the fan without modifying the assembling conditions with other elements. The invention aims to provide a heat-dissipating fan and a housing thereof, wherein an sidewall of the housing extends outwards to enlarge the intake airflow area thereof.

2. A typical electrical product includes electrical elements positioned in a closed housing to prevent contamination, but the electrical element tends to be consumed and its lifetime shortened due to high-temperature conditions. A fan is typically disposed in the housing to dissipate heat to the outside and prevent the electrical element from failing.

3. The conventional fan is mainly composed of a fan housing and an impeller, with the fan housing including an air inlet and an air outlet in communication with the air inlet via a central, cylindrical air passage. The air streams caused by the impeller may freely flow into and out of the fan housing via the air passage.

4. However, due to the restriction in the dimension of the rectangular fan housing of the conventional fan, the air passage at the lateral side has to be reduced, resulting in a wasted space and material of the fan housing. The optimized design in the shape of the blade based on the curve of the air passage is also restricted.

5. The invention aims to provide a heat-dissipating fan and a housing thereof, wherein an sidewall of the housing extends outwards to enlarge the intake airflow area thereof without modifying the assembling conditions between the existing fan and other heat dissipation elements. The shape of the housing at the air outlet side is kept unchanged in order to enhance the heat-dissipating efficiency of the fan.

6. The heat-dissipating device includes an impeller and a housing for receiving the impeller, wherein the housing includes a passage for guiding air streams to flow from an opening to another opening, and an sidewall of the passage at least one of the opening sides extends radially outwards so as to enlarge an intake/discharge area for the air streams.

7. The sidewall of the passage extends radially outwardly with respect to a central axis of the passage in a symmetrical manner, and the sidewall of the passage extends radially outwardly with respect to a longitudinal axis of the passage and beyond the peripheral edge of the outer frame. The sidewall of the passage is formed with an inclined portion or a beveled edge there around.

<summary>

The present invention relates to an electroluminescent display panel that can display different colors according to the situations without using an intermediate electrode, and can selectively display images in a color including no visible red components or in a color including visible red components with a high luminance.
2. The display panel is composed of various layers laminated on a glass substrate, including a first electrode layer, a first insulation layer, a first luminescent layer, a second luminescent layer, a second insulation layer, and a second electrode layer, which are all laminated in this order on the glass substrate.
